reviewText:
Even if I give the game a thumbs up, this one is not for me. There are a few things that really put me off from playing through this game. The combat system is horrible. Fallout 3 struggled to not become a FPS and somehow it worked for the most part, but in this game it just doesn't work either way. It's not a FPS and not an action RPG either. The loot system has been 'simplified' to a point where you keep getting the same items over and over again. You can modify weapons and ammo though.

The story is okay, but it didn't really catch me. Maybe the quite obvious build up for the main character to become the saviour of the universe was a bit too much. The voice acting for the main character does its part by simply being not good.

You can travel to other systems than the ones covered by the main story, but they are boring and at best filled with some generic structures without any deeper meaning. You explore those planets using a vehicle that has one of the worst controls and physics I've ever encountered in a computer game.

The visuals are good for a game from 2008, but the music doesn't really work for the title. It's very bland electronic music that would rather fit in an elevator.

I won't finish the game even if I invested over 16 hours into it so far as I don't see it becoming really interesting and the overall gameplay is just not satisfying. Why I still give it a thumbs up? I still think it's worth a try even if I personally don't like it.

reviewText: So I’m a bit slowpoke.jpg on this game. It was first developed for the Xbox 360 and later ported to the PC and PS3. The game came out in 2007, and seven years later I get down to playing it. First off, the maps were really difficult to read. I often had issues figuring out where the hell I was supposed to go. Then there were the freaking elevators. Elevator Sim 2007. Everywhere you went there were 13 elevators with 13 different awkward elevator conversations. No more elevators pls. There were some glitch’s with the gameplay itself, falling into trenches, not being able to move, getting stuck etc. The biggest issue I had was starting the actual game itself. Be aware that many computers have issues with starting or playing this game up. There are several forums that discuss different methods to fix this problem. Overall what really makes this game amazing is the storyline. Okay I’ll admit the lore went over my head, but it was really an interesting story. You get to choose whether you’re renegade or paragon, meaning are you an asshat or an asskisser? Either way you’re still an ♥♥♥. Stick all your points in charm or intimidate to get more dialogue options. The sound effects were spot on, graphics… what can you say? 2007. But the voice acting was aweesssoooommmmmeeeee. The character designs were really interesting as well. Can’t wait to play the second one. Also who the hell wears pink and white to a battlefield? Oh that’s Ashley. 9/10

reviewText:
This game is very near to perfect. If you like RPG, this will quite literally give you a galaxy's worth of role playing.
I'll start with the things that don't matter hugely to an RPG, but add to it and bring it to perfection. Firstly, the graphics are beautiful. Individually, tree leaves may look a little pixelated, and close-up shots of weaponry and armour suffer the same effect. However, when the graphics are bought together as a whole the effect is simply profound. Vast cityscapes sprawl beneath the viewing deck on the Citadel's wards, amazing scenery from the Presidium. All the skyboxes are filled with amazing imagery; binary star systems, meteorite showers, even simply beautiful blue skies and white clouds. Tying it all together are the little graphic effects, such as the lifelike water, or whisps of smoke and steam. Detailing on the characters, aliens, and animals are all done excelently, making the alien species not only believable, but also emotionally telling even when blue or scaley. Add to this very effective use of lighting and colours, and the option to have a 'film grain' graphics setting, and you are left with a game that is just beautiful.
Next, the music and sounds on this game are very well suited to the gameplay. As with most RPGs, the music seems to crescendo with each new adventure or battle, however at points in this game it also brings in much more somber and melancholly sounding music to reflect the emotions of the charecters and crew aboard the Normandy. In either case, the music always seems to reflect the fact that this is a game anbout space, and definitely adds to the other-worldly feel. The sound effects in the game are not necessarilly subtle, however when playing they become absorbed into the gameplay, something which personally I applaud. All to often I find myself turning down the sound effect volume on a game for it being to loud, or doing the complete opposite as it's too quiet to hear an enemy right behind you. With Mass Effect, all of the sounds effects are well designed so that they fit perfectly into context, and are never out of place. The voice acting in this game is spot on, all the characters are capable of so much emotion, and make the game so much more believable than counterparts with lesser vocals. Even alien races have voices to match, and a variety within the races at that, rather than the same voice actor for every member of a species (Skyrim, guards, what?).
Gameplay moves fluidly, whith characters interacting very well with the environment. I don't think I ever found a character floating in mid air, or stuck inside a boulder or staircase, or limbs from a character on one side of a door potruding through to the other side. Charecters take cover when commanded, are able to peer and shoot around objects, and team commands work excelently when directed, and still work well when on automatic. Customisation of you and your team's loadout was most definitely confusing at first, however once grasped really gave the combat situations an extra tactical element, allowing choices between weapons and ammunition types for each new enemy encountered. Added to the game is a hacking minigame which allows you to unlock doors, crates and safes, and this increases with difficulty as it increases with reward, however it would have been nice for the developers to add other methods of hacking - I doubt all locks in the galaxy use the exact same system. Effectively the game has 3 levels of gameplay, the most important being on foot, secondly missions involving driving the mako, and lastly small elements from being in orbit. When in orbit you are free to walk around and interact with your spaceship, and have access to the galaxy map. From this map you can explore the galaxy through nebulas, star systems and down to an individual planetary level. This allows you to scan planets for resources, and choose to land on some of the planets to perform a mission. When on minor missions on other planets, usually you will be assigned to drive the mako, an armoured six wheeled heavy hitting tank of sorts. Equiped with some form of machine gun, a slower firing cannon, and the ability to fly for a very brief period of time, it is fun to use. The controls are a bit strange at first, with the turning not behaving quite as you'd expect, however once you've gotten used to it, the driving becomes a lot more fun.
Finally, the part most people want from an RPG to be perfect is the story, the character interactions, quite simply, the role playing. This game SATISFIES. In playing this game you can either simply blast through the main missions and skip the dialogue, missing out the majority of the context and background, or you can take the time to talk to minor characters, pick up side missions, and simply use dialogue options to ask questions. All of these actions add a hugely deep and mixed background for the in-game galaxy, with complex interactions and repercussions of past actions echoed in the game you get to play, although possibly misunderstood or simply missed if the player choses to ignore them. If the interactions themselves didn't satisfy, the game has a 'codex', which is basically an encyclopedia which fills as you play and interact, meaning that if at any point you forget something you've picked up or simply want to learn more about an aspect of the game (with a large scope, from biology and cuture of alien races, to the weapons and armour used on the Normandy) you can delve into the codex and gain a better understanding. The storyline is believable, and multiple storylines can be followed through the use of paragon (hero) or renegade (badass) options. This allows for much greater depth and character development, and continues with your choices in the first game bridging over into the sequels. The paragon/renegade choice also shapes the way you interact with individual characters, bringing different methods of conflict resolution, persuading your way through tough situations, or even romance with the choice being left to the player. Character interactions are usually emotionally charged without being unreal, and these emotions build as you become closer to your crew, leading to some very hard decisions in the late game.
Overall, this is one of my most favourite games I've ever played since I started on a Windows 95 at the age of 2. I fell in love on my first playthrough, and it definitely brings an amazing sense of gravitas with it. The game is deep, moving, and most importantly believable. Grapics, audio, and gameplay elements tie the whole package together in a beautiful way, and pull the player in deeper. I'd easilly give this a 9/10, and would recomend this to anyone with even a slight love of RPG. Simply put, buy this game, play it, and cherish it.

reviewText: Mass Effect is a sexual rollercoaster. One minute, your ♥♥♥♥ is starting to tremble from the adrenaline that you feel as you're slaughtering dozens of unarmed colonists, the next you're getting rammed by a Krogan warlord. And nothing quite prepares you for the initial feeling of going balls deep in an Asari scientist, as you pull on her ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little tentacles. And lemme tell ya, this octopus doesn't trim her garden (Geddit?! Pubic hair comments with Beatles references!) However, the most powerful experience this game gives the player is the possibility to take advantage of an Easter egg in which you can anally probe a Geth, which shows how hard the developers worked to hold true to their sci-fi roots. reviewText: Belated review. If you are a sucker for any of the following: spaceships, aliens, storytelling, RPGs, shooters, or sci-fi in general, and haven't yet played Mass Effect... well, what are you waiting for?!? Even though it's a few years old now and has a few minor problems, Mass Effect is still well-worth playing, especially if you have any interest at all in the upcoming ME3. I thought overall it was a really fun game, especially the story aspects. The shooting mechanics are also perfectly fine. The only major gripe I had was the weapon/inventory system. Throughout your journey, you are constantly finding tons of weapons and upgrades, 99% of which are duplicates or unneccessary. The interface for managing weapons is also confusing and cumbersome. But that one thing aside, I pretty much loved everything else about ME1. If you haven't played it yet, get it now!

reviewText:
No one likes to display their closet nerd stuff out in public.

There are only about 4 types of game related shirts I come across that people seem okay with wearing out into public without getting massive wedgies from everyone.

Halo or Call of Duty something (shooter nerds trying to act like they're not nerds chugging all that Mountain Dew)
A Horde or Alliance symbol (Warcraft nerds)
Anything Nintendo related (Nintendo's cool but Super Smash Brothers on Steam is the future come on Reggie Fils make it happen...)
The mysterious N7 symbol (You'll see well groomed, attractive, a-list type folks whom you're sure couldn't possibly be into games strutting around in these)
Yes, the N7 symbol that comes from Mass Effect.  People walk around wearing this in real life with beaming pride.  The amount of respect for the symbolic designation of Commander Sheppard's training in interplanetary warfare (The N7 ranking) is huge amongst fans.  The distribution of Commander Sheppard's Jersey (N7) may very well rival the amount of wear and public exposure as some semi-popular professional athelete jerseys.

Mass Effect is here to stay...indefinitely.  With this first game a giant amount of gamers became life long fans.  It's amazing to see the sheer diversity of people who have become so attached to the universe and the characters.  People cosplay the characters and go to conventions even though the trilogy for Mass Effect has reached its conclusion long ago.  (No worries, there are definitely more Mass Effect games to come).

Along with Dragon Age, Baldur's Gate and Knights of the Old Republic, this would be another example of Bioware's dedication to crafting intense stories and deep characters that people can really dive deep into.

The Game
Mass Effect is a Space RPG focused on story and character development.  The conversation wheel is used frequently to allow the character to engage in discussions with other NPCs and teammates they encounter during gameplay.

In this game you play as the commander of an elite team consisting of the galaxy's most skilled interstellar fighters in a mission to save the galaxy.  It's essentially a third person, cover shooter where you can issue commands to your teammates to strategically position them and to use special abilities on enemies.

You can fight with what is essentially Star Wars-esque Force Powers
Along with all manner of space guns: Rifles, Sniper Rifles, Pistols, Shotguns, automatics and so on.

Pros Great Gameplay mechanics
Excellent Story
Excellent Character Design (People are obsessed with their favorite characters)
Excellent Visuals
Very elaborate RPG elements
Choices made can impact the of outcome events both immediately and in later games (This is the first part of a trilogy)
Cons Inventory can get a little cluttered
There's a rare chance that you can encounter a catastrophic bug in a few places that will prevent you from progressing (must reload your last save) Save Often
The entire trilogy isn't available on Steam....blame Electronic Arts.
If you enjoy Sci Fi and RPGs, this game is a no brainer.  You've probably played it already.  If you haven't...now's the time...

reviewText:
I have tried a few times to play this game. Last time hard drive broke so I thought I might try again as I was enjoying it.

Its really good, a great sci fi game. Really good story a good start to series and still stands up well as an older game.

For me its not the most indepth game character wise from Bioware. I did really like the characters and story but it just didnt feel as indepth as Dragon Age.  Its still a really good game well worth playing and Mass Effect 2 is supposed to be amazing.

It feels a little slower paced which I dont mind. The side missions some just seem dull and pointless but some of the rewards are pretty cool and do make it worth your while. The character missions I always like to do as I like to get to know the characters but all in all I just wanted to get on with the story which is a shame because theres a galaxy to explore.

The characters were cool but it seemed most of it was set up to make you have a relationship with someone. I mean it didnt seem to matter what i said to one of the characters something was gonna happen lol.

Still a cool game though.

reviewText:
Mass Effect is a must have.

Simply because it kicked off the most sophisticated Sci-Fi IP of the past 30 years. The richness and depth of the Mass Effect Series' universe is easily on par with Star Wars and Star Trek. If you are a Sci-Fi Fan you can not help but get sucked in and swallowed whole by this beast.

As a game the strength of Mass Effect besides it's lore is a superb story within that lore, believable Charaters to interact with, choices over choices that impact not only the current game but reach forward into part 3 and some of the best written and performed dialog of all time.

Within the series this is the game featuring the most Exploration opportunities and the strongest classical RPG elements (VERY stat and skill dependant down to a limit in inventory space, lots of loot).

The weak points:

Bugs. It's a problem with the whole series. There is nothing gamebreaking, but some Bugs are just plain out annoying and stupid but never got fixed. My guess is that this is in no small part due to the fact that the Mass Effect games are made for consoles first and foremost and are from a console era when patching wasn't really an option.

While the Exploration possibilities are quite big it sadly isn't done very well. Most of it consists of driving a vehicle with crazy physics through randomly generated height maps that had a few prefabs placed in them. That is litterally something that a hobbyist just learning how to make maps can put together in an hours work or less.

The list of weak points could be made longer.

But in reality they do not matter. Because the story and how it is presented not only makes up for the weak points. It lets you forget them. I am just in the middle of another series playthrough just because I have finally gotten all DLCs for part 3. And this probably is the strongest pro going for the series: Even though you could play just part 3. When you pick it up again you wanna start at the beginning again. With Part 1. Because seeing a new Shepard evolve and change over the course of three games is just awesome. It is just like those Lord of the Ring or Star Wars weekends when you watch all the movies in succession. Only better because it lasts for weeks. Hell a 100% completion playthrough of all three games is worth easily 150 hours of playtime.

Last but not Least: Another important reason to get the Mass Effect Series is that part 4 is rumored to hit us next year at the latest and you absolutely will want to know what all the fuss is about when that happens.

reviewText: Mass Effect is expressed more freely than ever and offers an exciting adventure, set in a beautifully coherent universe. Mass Effect is their greatest achievement thus far. Once again, thank you to Bioware for such generosity.\n\n18/20

reviewText:
Oh Mass Effect, such nostalgia, much wow. It's been nearly 8 years since the initial launch of Bioware's Space Epic and to this day the industry is still learning from it. Mass Effect 2 brought serious improvements to the ME universe however the original Mass Effect is a classic. The Morality system where a player could either become a Paragon (Good) or a Renegade (Bad) was similar to the likes of the Good and Evil system of games like Fable however it actually awarded the player with satisfaction. Every decision point actually effected how you played the game.

The planet exploration system in Mass Effect has and always will be amazing, roaming planets with the Mako Rover was fun but awkward at times due to the mechanics however this was improved vastly in Mass Effect 2. When using the Mass Relay system to teleport from one relay to another you would get a decent animation that was followed by a stunning central planet followed by it's surrounding plants. The galaxy's that filled the space in between were stunning as well, with a high fidelity of stars and more it was a sight for the eyes that I have not forgotten to this day.

Actual combat was fairly decent however again it was vastly improved in Mass Effect 2. If you ever need a great game or series to play, something you plan to put at least a hundred plus hours into, the Mass Effect trilogy is a great choice however I suggest you prepare yourself for the ending of Mass Effect 3, don't say I didn't warn you about that one. If this game's on sale for $4.99 or even $19.99 BUY IT and the other two Mass Effect games as well (Mass Effect 3 is only available on Origin sadly, thanks EA).

reviewText:
This is my first review so please don't hate!

Mass Effect 1 is the first of the ME trilogy, one of the best RPG trilogies of today.

Despite lacking the better graphics of the later 2 games, the story is still extreemly well made, the characters are just amazing to play, talk and experiment with, lots of quest and places to explore (for those who love completing the games as much as possible and have the patience to do it)

Unfortunately it still has some bugs in it, but most people have found ways around them if you look around for fixes, at least i managed to fix 2-3 more known bugs such as the sound crackle, starmap bug and quicksave bug.

It is one of my favorite games of all time, Bioware has the most talented dev's from my point of view so bear with the graphics and play your way trough this trilogy, its well worth every single penny.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this game

Pros-
-The story is well crafted and you can tell alot of effort was put into it. It has lots of twists, turns, and reveals that are pretty good. Not mind blowing, but still, its one of the highlights of the game. Theres alot there if you want to dig giving players a choice in how far they want to go into the lore of the worle.
-Interactions with your squad members are memorable and personal. Each has distinct personalities and underlying motives that are there if you spend the time to get to know them all
-The branching diolauge paths are great. Give some depth and a player's touch into the game. Not super deep and many diolauges still lead to the exact same result but thats ok.
-The settings were pretty good. It was really neat to go explore all these planets and choose in what order you were to do it in. The aliens and universe created here are also interesting and thought out.
-Runs well on my crap PC and also has a widespread texture mod for those who seek higher fidelity.

Cons
-Elevators. There are alot of them. Most I assume are disgusing loading screens and it really gets old fast especially when in some situations you go through one elevator, get out, walk a bit, then go up another.
-Combat. While it is good I wouldnt call it great. I played on the hardest difficulty with AI actions turned off for my squad mates and one of two things would happen in combat situations: my main character could just wipe out all the enemies without the help of my squadmates so I have no reason to even have them do anything, or when I do need them they are HORRIBLE at staying alive. Even when you direct them towards cover they very often come out for no reason and die. Somtimes you plan a combo of abilities on a enemy all at once but one squad member decides that its just not happening today. It got annoying. Also I didnt like that you had to pick your squadmates from the begining of the mission when you have no idea whats in store. They all have different abilities but only a few combos cover everything so it locks you out of doing certain combos of characters you may like. Overall it is an ok combat system, that with some tweaks could be really really good.
-Driving sections - controls are kind of slippery and every driving section all game has the same 3 or 4 enemies making them really easy and really boring
-Enemies. There are only about 10 enemys in the whole game if you dont count reskins. Kind of a a let down.
-Final Boss- Ended up just being the main bad guy with the abilities of one of the enemy types you have fought all game with a stupid amount of health and rocket launchers added on. I get that the combat doesnt really lend itself to grandiose boss battles but still. Boss battles in general were usually just waves of common enemies.
-Save points, This is the grandaddy of my annoyances with this game. Probably 5-10 times thoughout the main game you will have boss battles or very difficult encounters that have loooong cutscenes or elevators right before them. These cannot be skipped and its awful. Every time you die you have to walk through the same diolauge for 2 minutes before you fight. It gets old really fast espeicailly if you are having a real tough time with the boss. I get not skipping on the first time but there is no reason you shouldnt be able to skip on subsequent viewings.

Overall I did really enjoy this game. This is a game that is greater than the sum of its parts. It keep me wanting to play to figure out what would happen next which cant be said for too many games I play. If you like a good space story and third person tactical shooters, I would grab this game. 7.5/10

reviewText: After seeing snippets of Mass Effect 2, I knew I had to play from the beginning. This game is a great start to this three part space opera. The story is deceptively simple. You are Commander Shephard and you must save the galaxy. As you complete the simple story you will have to make decisions that will flesh out the story and in some ways decide on who lives and who dies. Apart from the main story, there are numerous side missions that help develop relationships with fellow characters or influence what happens in the sequels. There is tons of replay value due to the fact that there are different ways to handle various situations in the game. The graphics have aged well, I think. The characters are all memorable. You won't like these characters, you will LOVE them. The relationships you build (or tear down) will follow you in the games to come. Now for the negatives, and I had to squint to see them. I personally found the exploration tedious. The planets you go to are all very detailed, with descriptions about their resources and history, but driving the vehicle to go through some of the rough terrain got to be annoying at times. Thats really the only negative I could think of. A great game that should be tried by everybody.

reviewText:
What can be said about Mass Effect that hasn't already been said?

Mechanically, it's a third-person shooter/RPG hybrid with interactive, choice-driven cinematics interspersed regularly.

There are certainly problems with that. The conversations and cinematics wind up taking up, quite literally, most of your time--except of course the endless backtracking on the Normandy and Mako portions--and making the game feel more like a visual novel than a Western action-RPG at times. It feels more like a story and less like a game, some of the time. Most of the time, really.

The RPG leveling is good, but nowhere near as good as, say, Skyrim's, or the original Deus Ex's. (I say the original because I have yet to play Human Revolution, not because I object to it in any way.) The levels you wind up focusing on are Charm and Intimidate, whose primary impact involves, you guessed it, the cinematic conversations. There's the electronics and decryption skill trees, sure (although they're more just lines than trees--for a game centered around choice-based narrative, there's not much choice-based gameplay) which allow you to access increasingly more advanced resources, but if you just bring one of your three tech-savvy squadmates and fully spec them to those trees, you can deal with any of those unlicks from about three hours in, which kind of renders the piont moot. That's good, though, because the alternative is yet more Mako scenes as you backtrack to planets you've already seen once you can access the resources on them.

The shooter portion, which is the part you actually play, has fewer concrete issues. You point and shoot. It's just lackluster. The sniper rifles are unsteady in a rather blatant nod to Deus Ex--they get better as you level them. Pistols are pretty much slightly slower assault rifles. Shotguns are bizzarely effective over long ranges. Assault Rifles, which only Soldier-class characters can train, are actually quite viable for non-soldier characters, to the point where on higher difficulties the game is almost impossible if you  forget about them.

The biggest issues I have are with certain enemies and level design. The Geth units which jump around the area are almost impossible to hit, especially if you haven't got a controller mod installed. There is the occasional open level where sniper rifles are viable, but a lot of the game is played at close-quarters to the enemy, which renders snipers useless. Annoying, since I like the Infiltrator class's tech abilities combines with combat proficiency, since biotics are very hard to use in this first game.

But in spite of all that, Mass Effect works, mechanically speaking. Nothing is broken. I wouldn't come back to it for the gameplay, but it's not painful to play--unless you're in the Mako and trying to 100% every planet, in which case, you have my sympathies.

Where Mass Effect--and Bioware in general--shine is in narrative. Mass Effect--the first game, not the trilogy--does a fantastic job of creating a setting and telling a story in it. It's a bit bland compared to its two sequels, I'll be honest. It doesn't have the thematic subtext those games do. Mass Effect 1 is nothing more than it claims to be: a story which provides you a template--Shepard--and lets you play with him or her how you choose. But that much it does incredibly well.

There are few scenes in a video game that have aged as well as the first meeting with Sovereign on Virmire or the conversation with Vigil on Ilos. Despite the ridiculous texture glitch on Garrus' face, we start to get a real feel for one of the best characters in gaming in this game, and he is fun, especially when in an elevator with Tali or Wrex so they can yell at each other.

The less said about elevators, the better, of course.

The romances are a bit dull, I will admit. Your choices are Kaidan, Ashley, and Liara. Kaidan is bland, Ashley is xenophobic, and Liara never uses contractions because at this point Bioware still thought that was a cool way to make a character mysterious. I guess Liara's the best choice, but it's a bit like deciding which cheap shoe looks least cheap.

Wow, I'm really bashing the game aren't I? Yeah, it's flawed. Really flawed. But it works. The first playthrough can be incredibly immersive. Saren is a great villain, most of the time, and a good one overall. Sovereign is truly chilling. You feel like something is at stake, by the end of the game, although it never quite reaches the emotional peaks at the last levels of Mass Effect 2 and 3.

All in all, it's not a masterpiece, but it's a fun game, and one well worth a purchase, even when it's not on sale. When it is on sale, you'd be a fool not to get it.

reviewText:
Excelent and very involving. The game offers you a rich scenario, with plenty of things to do. The game mechanics are a bit unconfortable, but it gets fun once you get used to it. Soundtrack is beautiful and well suited, the plot is very well designed, involving and fun to uncover. The graphics are old, but they are good enough. Characteres are the main strength of the game I think: very complex personalities, many possible interactions and dialogue outcomes. You will never few like you are talking to the same NPC, regardeless if he is a shopper, guard, squad member or quest-NPC. They are so well design you can few pity or foundness for some of them.

The game have weaknesses , I can say that for one thing, money is useless. Yes, you can buy some interesting upgrades and weapons/armors with it. But it is definitely not a must, you can go just fine with the loots you find in mission. The few upgrades you can't find in mission (like extra medi-gel capacity for instance) are so cheap it doesen't really few you are spending anything. Speaking of upgrades, those are another weak spot of the game. Too many of those and they don't look so different. When you less expect you will be carrying too many of those and not knowing good combinations. I also expected some spaceship warefare...but the game has none. The character role I picked has also some kind of a problem. As an infiltrator, the best combat strategy I have has to sniper-shoot everyone...and cry if an enemy get to close, since I don't have any other effective trained weapon to use. One would expect some sort of clock ability - they fixed that in ME 2, fortunately.

But those are minor weaknesses. I would score the game 4 out of 5.

reviewText:
This game is absolutely brilliant. I didn't realize how much better the first game is ME2 and ME3, until i started replaying ME1 the other day. Grand nostalgia started kicking in and the epicness of this game is on a scale unmatched by any other space game. The level-up system is fleshed out, the characters are fleshed out, decisions have big impacts and the combat is tactical, difficult and awesome. Also, the inventory I happen to like quite a bit, when most people hate it. But thanks to so many people hating it, BioWare completely got rid of it and stripped the game of it's other most important RPG elements for ME2 and ME3.

Mass Effect 1 is to ME2 and ME3 what Dragon Age Origins is to Dragon Age 2. The first game of both series' were epic beyond the likes of any other game in it's genre and had so much content it kept you wide-eyed and fully entrapped by it's charm. While the sequels were just stripped down of the best features they once had. Though I have to say that ME2 is still a pretty entertaining and fun game, but didn't do justice to the original.

To say the least, if you enjoy space games or RPGs, then this game is a must and you'll probably love it. Admittedly it does take a few hours to really get into the game and the tactical combat takes some getting used to, but it's great fun once you learn. That's all good in my opinion. I enjoy having to learn a  game rather than being thrown into it and it being the same as every other game in it's genre. This game will take you on one of the most memorable journeys you've ever been on in gaming and it will captivate you the entire way through, from the grand music, to the tactical combat, to the storytelling, etc.

On a side not, a lot of people also didn't like exploring planets with the Mako, but I think that's one of the best parts. It's fun discovering materials/items and uncovering the secrets of some planets and completing quests on others. Again, if you like space, this game is definitely for you.

reviewText:
Mass Effect 3 was my first Mass Effect game to play when it came out a while back; however, I decided to give the whole triolgy a new start after I bought the first two as a bundle during some Steam sale. I didn't quite remember all the details from ME3, which was good, but I knew enough about the Mass Effect world to where I wasn't completely lost. With that said, finally figuring out all the backstory and references made in ME3 was amazing.

Story-wise, the Mass Effect universe is on par with Star Wars and Star Trek. The charaters are developed extremely well, with well thought out insight in each different species. The dialogue and choices are superb. At the end of the day, when you finally save and exit the game, you feel as if you were part of the action. Part of Commander Shepard's odyssey. Going back to reality was always a bummer.

Combat-wise the controls were a little loose. Then again, this game is about 7 years old at this point. You get use to the controls, but do not expect very responsive actions and features that most games have today. Most of the side quests (assignments) felt like chores at the end, but I still wanted to get them all done to explore the awesome ME universe. Customization is also not as well-developed as the sequels are. Many times I get stuck with a Shepard wearing a ridiculous looking armour but the stats on it are amazing so I couldn't argue. The decision making (Paragon/Renegade) also provides unique story, meticulous and sometimes stressful choices, and good replayability, even if much of the story is progressively linear.

In the end, I can understand why Mass Effect is so popular. The universe draws you in and the gripping story, dialogue, and action make you want to play this game until you have played it 3+ times, exhausting all the different dialogue choices, actions, and play styles you can make in the game. Worth the money. Worth the time. You will regret nothing besides some of the grueling choices you have to make along the way to save the galaxy. But that's what makes this game, this series, perfect.

reviewText:
This game is great fun. I couldn't recommended it more. The graphics are good, the gameplay is engaging and the voice acting is good. Jenifer Hale does a great job voicing fem shep, (don't play the male shep line because it is that good). The great thing about the choices you make in this game is that they carry over into the next two games. There is strong support for this game from the community which is super useful if your suck.
Some things (which aren't necessarily bad just noteable):

somepeople may find it unusual playing this game without the jump feature (particularly if you havent played a game without it)
the game is getting on now and you may need to put it into compatiability mode or give admin rights, and some people may want to tweak a few settings (there are heaps of tweak guides out there)
you want to save, lots. even just to save yourself if a very rare glitch happens but its very easy to get sucked into this game and forget to save, and then to lose all your progress. But there are relatively frequent autosaves.

It has serious replayabilty too, which is an added bonus. Also, there are dlc for this game one free and one you can pay for both adds to the game but not necessary there is loads of content.
i hope you have as much fun playing this game as i have.

reviewText:
While perhaps not worth the hype the series has generated over the years, this game is still very good. I really enjoyed the story, and the way it progressed really impressed me. The supporting cast aren't that great (something they improved in Mass Effect 2, sadly with the loss of the great story) but the fact that Shepard develops how you want him to while still remaining an interesting character is no mean feat.

It is quite annoying that some conversations that give you options just ignore your choices and just go straight into what the game wants, and I guess it would be tough to make a game which allowed all that but then making games is tough. So I would've liked more freedom to do what I wanted rather than just what the game dictated. Nobody likes a game pretending you have a choice and then just ignoring it. That's just not cool.

The combat is perfectly acceptable. I heartily recommend going with the combat-biotic fusion character as then you get the most fun out of your character while still remaining a heavy hitter with weapons. The squad-part of combat is really not at all important, as your squad is not all that effective and they can just about handle themselves. I'm quite glad that they did that though, as I prefer having a squad that does their own thing. They could have made them slightly more clever however.

Overall, a very good game with a few drawbacks. Not a brilliant game, but a very good game nonetheless.

reviewText:
And it begins! This game is incredible. I played this game close to 7 years after its release and it's still amazing. This game is perfect. The story is absolutely engrossing and something you can submerge yourself into, it's like a modern day Star Wars. The characters in this game are so well developed, the grow on you to the point you'll always consider them life long friends. This is an action RPG and the game lives up to that classification. The action is just as riveting as the decisions you'll need to make over the course of the game. Never before has a game put me on the edge of my seat, regarding the consequences of choices I've made. I love the freedom this game offers. The tension builds and builds as you reach the climax. The game play is intuitive and an enjoyable experience. As you build your characters skillsets, you experience such a natural incline of abilites and you can lots of options to build a character with combat skills suited to your preferences. This is game you'll remember.

Interested in Mass Effect 2 or 3? Not sure if you'll enjoy Mass Effect because it's almost a decade old? Buy this game, you will not be dissapointed. Not only will it enrich your experience for Mass Effect 2 and 3, it's just downright a great game. You'll soon realize the more Mass Effect in your life, the better.

Hell, I even suffered through playing Mass Effect 3 on origin....that's how great this game is!

reviewText:
Not quite the full kilo

MASS EFFECT is a mixed bag of a game: everything about it is good in some ways but not in others. The most notable achievement perhaps is the rich storyline and detailed universe created by the developers (there is plenty to read here -- I started by reading every word but confess to scanning some texts as the game progressed). The graphics are good in parts but not in others (I know this game came out in 2007 but then so did Crysis). The voice acting is overall pretty good and there are plenty of branches to the dialogue trees. And this is where MASS EFFECT’s strengths lie: in the role playing aspects of the game. You’re given the opportunity to be the good guy or the not so good guy, depending on how you wish to play. Less successful is the combat, which, for the most part, failed to engage. Also the side missions are very repetitive and dull. The vehicle you get to drive on numerous occasions bounces around like a drunken bouncy thing, and there are endless elevators that take too long to ascend or descend. Oh, and the UI for selecting skills, weapons etc. is needlessly complex.
Overall MASS EFFECT is worth playing but the whole experience is oddly detached and vaguely unsatisfying. I have MASS EFFECT 2 also. I understand it’s much improved on the first.

3/5
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Bioware once again creates an epic RPG! The strength of Mass Effect lies in its narrative that is supplemented by the in-game Codex which painstakingly lays out the future history of Earth, technology and the various alien races. The gameplay involves simple shoot ‘n cover tactics followed by lengthy sessions of exploration and character dialogue. Compared to its sequel and other RPGs, Mass Effect can become a bit tedious when you choose to explore the various planets and again so when it comes to upgrading and managing your equipment. However, these mishaps are easily overshadowed by the game’s plot that will leave sci-fi & RPG fans craving for more of the universe. There are two DLC packs available for Mass Effect: Bring Down the Sky (FREE upon registering) and Pinnacle Station ($5, not worth it).

reviewText:
If I were a sci-fi film director, I would try my best to pursuade EA so that I can make movies or TV series out of the story.
The story and its depth is the thing that made this game special.

Game mechanics are good, somewhat hard to get on, but they're OK. You can build your playing character; what's his class (which will determine his strength and weak point), what he looks like, you can change your first name but not your surname (it's Shepard, I myself am Rudi Shepard in the game). You do battle in team and to a degree you can tell what your teammates suppose to do, although the AI lacks a lot in this respect. The battle is fun, but can get frustating in some boss fights if you're underleved and choose unsinergized skills.

This is a sci-fi RPG classic. Must have for a sci-fi fan.

reviewText:
Excelent and very involving. The game offers you a rich scenario, with plenty of things to do. The game mechanics are a bit unconfortable, but it gets fun once you get used to it. Soundtrack is beautiful and well suited, the plot is very well designed, involving and fun to uncover. The graphics are old, but they are good enough. Characteres are the main strength of the game I think: very complex personalities, many possible interactions and dialogue outcomes. You will never few like you are talking to the same NPC, regardeless if he is a shopper, guard, squad member or quest-NPC. They are so well design you can few pity or foundness for some of them.

The game have weaknesses , I can say that for one thing, money is useless. Yes, you can buy some interesting upgrades and weapons/armors with it. But it is definitely not a must, you can go just fine with the loots you find in mission. The few upgrades you can't find in mission (like extra medi-gel capacity for instance) are so cheap it doesen't really few you are spending anything. Speaking of upgrades, those are another weak spot of the game. Too many of those and they don't look so different. When you less expect you will be carrying too many of those and not knowing good combinations. I also expected some spaceship warefare...but the game has none. The character role I picked has also some kind of a problem. As an infiltrator, the best combat strategy I have has to sniper-shoot everyone...and cry if an enemy get to close, since I don't have any other effective trained weapon to use. One would expect some sort of clock ability - they fixed that in ME 2, fortunately.

But those are minor weaknesses. I would score the game 4 out of 5.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Perhaps the pinnacle of my experiences in the sci-fi genre. Something about the universe entraps me, making the world feel just believable enough while posing advances in science and sociology to retain the brilliance of science fiction. It gives a chance to make the character your own, with options that make you observe what you want to say, instead of having an idea of what will be 'good guy' or 'badass'. The universe offers a lot of reward for exploring and enterprise, making the game far longer than the set story.

There are shortcomings obviously. The combat has slight hard-spots but its largely cooperative. Sometimes its worth saving before dialogue just to make sure you don't pick an option that you later find 'misleading'. Lastly, new OS's don't always get along with the game. I had to run Windows Software Troubleshoot to make it work, and afterwards the steam overlay stopped working.

All in all, I encourage anyone who enjoys a game for its story and its gameplay, to fully immerse themselves in this series.

reviewText:
While perhaps not worth the hype the series has generated over the years, this game is still very good. I really enjoyed the story, and the way it progressed really impressed me. The supporting cast aren't that great (something they improved in Mass Effect 2, sadly with the loss of the great story) but the fact that Shepard develops how you want him to while still remaining an interesting character is no mean feat.

It is quite annoying that some conversations that give you options just ignore your choices and just go straight into what the game wants, and I guess it would be tough to make a game which allowed all that but then making games is tough. So I would've liked more freedom to do what I wanted rather than just what the game dictated. Nobody likes a game pretending you have a choice and then just ignoring it. That's just not cool.

The combat is perfectly acceptable. I heartily recommend going with the combat-biotic fusion character as then you get the most fun out of your character while still remaining a heavy hitter with weapons. The squad-part of combat is really not at all important, as your squad is not all that effective and they can just about handle themselves. I'm quite glad that they did that though, as I prefer having a squad that does their own thing. They could have made them slightly more clever however.

Overall, a very good game with a few drawbacks. Not a brilliant game, but a very good game nonetheless.

reviewText:
And it begins! This game is incredible. I played this game close to 7 years after its release and it's still amazing. This game is perfect. The story is absolutely engrossing and something you can submerge yourself into, it's like a modern day Star Wars. The characters in this game are so well developed, the grow on you to the point you'll always consider them life long friends. This is an action RPG and the game lives up to that classification. The action is just as riveting as the decisions you'll need to make over the course of the game. Never before has a game put me on the edge of my seat, regarding the consequences of choices I've made. I love the freedom this game offers. The tension builds and builds as you reach the climax. The game play is intuitive and an enjoyable experience. As you build your characters skillsets, you experience such a natural incline of abilites and you can lots of options to build a character with combat skills suited to your preferences. This is game you'll remember.

Interested in Mass Effect 2 or 3? Not sure if you'll enjoy Mass Effect because it's almost a decade old? Buy this game, you will not be dissapointed. Not only will it enrich your experience for Mass Effect 2 and 3, it's just downright a great game. You'll soon realize the more Mass Effect in your life, the better.

Hell, I even suffered through playing Mass Effect 3 on origin....that's how great this game is!

reviewText:
Not quite the full kilo

MASS EFFECT is a mixed bag of a game: everything about it is good in some ways but not in others. The most notable achievement perhaps is the rich storyline and detailed universe created by the developers (there is plenty to read here -- I started by reading every word but confess to scanning some texts as the game progressed). The graphics are good in parts but not in others (I know this game came out in 2007 but then so did Crysis). The voice acting is overall pretty good and there are plenty of branches to the dialogue trees. And this is where MASS EFFECT’s strengths lie: in the role playing aspects of the game. You’re given the opportunity to be the good guy or the not so good guy, depending on how you wish to play. Less successful is the combat, which, for the most part, failed to engage. Also the side missions are very repetitive and dull. The vehicle you get to drive on numerous occasions bounces around like a drunken bouncy thing, and there are endless elevators that take too long to ascend or descend. Oh, and the UI for selecting skills, weapons etc. is needlessly complex.
Overall MASS EFFECT is worth playing but the whole experience is oddly detached and vaguely unsatisfying. I have MASS EFFECT 2 also. I understand it’s much improved on the first.

3/5

reviewText: A fantastic space rpg with a very interesting universe and story. The game gives you a good deal of customization and has great character interaction. However, the combat is pretty mediocre third person shooter combat for the most part. The vehicle sections can also be quite awkward especially when you are playing the game for the first time. Despite these issues, the shooting is still somewhat satisfying and the game gives you a variety of abilities and weapon addons that make the combat much more interesting. You can get cryo ammo to freeze your enemy, or biotic power that allow you to through your enemies. You also have a good deal of control over you squad which adds a bit more depth to the combat.\n\n8/10

reviewText: Great futuristic RPG based on our universe in somewhat fantasy setting. You play as commander Shepard who is pretty much a one man, a one ship crew army. Wont spoil much, this game has great story, a lot of characters and character interaction via cut scene dialogues. Great galaxy to explore with a lot of planets to land on, stations to visit and side quests to do. Has a lot of choice and consequence so think carefully what you say, as the response will shape your character to be good or evil. Game has great visuals, voice acting and animations. Make sure you keep your saves if you plan on playing ME 2, ME 3, etc., as you can transfer them and keep your progress and story over to the next game. I enjoyed this a lot, one of the best if not the best sci-fi RPG of my time.

reviewText:
One of the great RPGs of our time. Mass Effect excells in storytelling and characterization in ways that no other game has. This particular title is most memorable (for me personally) because of the way it introduces and develops the characters in such a fashion that the player truly cares about their fate and building relationships with each and every one.

Mass Effect also has solid shooter mechanics. I actually prefer the overheating weapons over the thermal clips from the later games. I also enjoy the combat storm and the way it is incorporated into the strengths and weaknesses of any particular character build. The abilites and leveling are also extremely well executed. I personally found it so rewarding and satisfying that I achieved level 60, but regardless the leveling system successfully helps to add reward during a playthrough.

Again, however, what makes Mass Effect such an amazing game is its characters and story progression. To avoid spoilers, I will just say that by the time I was nearing the end of the main story for the first time, I was deeply invested in each individual character's story and that is something that I cannot say about almost any other game experience.

Mass Effect exemplifies the great strengths of BioWare in its prime and will forever be a gold standard to which I will compare future titles to.

reviewText:
I actually spent 20 hours in this game in the last 4 days in Steam offline mode, so ignore Steam playtime.

Mass Effect was a pleasant surprise for me, because of two reasons: I'm not a fan of space opera and sci-fi, and I couldn't get into one of Bioware's well known title - Dragon Age: Origins. But screw them, let's talk about Mass Effect. The game has messy inventory system, clunky animations, pretty straightforward weapon upgrades and doesn't allow progressing after finishing the main story, aaaaaaand... that's it, that's all my criticism for ME. What can I say more about it? Mass Effect is a well-crafted game from head to toe, with nearly all aspects perfected.

First, I freaking love the narrative. In the first 30 minutes, I thought it was some typical pretentious sci-fi piece of ♥♥♥♥ that overcomplicates everything, but nope, the story really hooked me in, even it was just a standard good-vs-evil story filled with cliches. I can't tell exactly what I love about ME's story, but it gave me a sense of real progression, and pushed me forward through each events in the game. Sometime intense, sometime emotional and sometime even silly (especially in romance subplots), and of course it doesn't lack epicness" for a sci-fi saga.

Next

reviewText:
Game:  Mass Effect 1
Genre:  RPG/FPS
Developer:  Bioware/EA
System:   Steam (PC)
Total Score: 93/100
Value Score: 9.3/10

• Story:  10/10
• Characters: 9/10
• GamePlay:  9/10
• Graphics:  8/10
• Sound: 10/10
• Music:  8/10
• Length: 9/10
• Replay Value: 10/10
• Player Value: 10/10

Pros
+Great Dynamic story that keeps changing depending on what role, what decisions and actions you make in the game.
+Multiple Scenarios, Paths and Endings which leads to multiple playthroughs and thus replay value
+Class based gameplay system which allows you to have a different experience each time you play as a different class.
+Character customization lets you create your own character in their own appearance, etc
+A great mixture of RPG and FPS elements packaged into one game
+Fantastic voice acting and a lot of voice over scenes
+A great morality system that also plays in what bonuses you would get (i.e. discounts, certain decision options)
+Leveling system has quite a depth that ranges from learning unique class abilities to weapon mastery
+Save files are interchangeable between Steam and Origin.

Cons
-Some minor glitches could occur such as falling into the floor or certain scenes not being playable from time to time but nothing game breaking and does not happen often or repeatedly
-Some of the visual designs look a bit outdated and last gen style (PS2/GCN/Xbox era)
-Some of the side missions lead you to similar to same looking areas and structures
-Some of the planets are so barren and empty with nothing but fetch quests or extra grinding for weapons and money.
-Pinnacle Station DLC is not available for standalone purchases of Mass Effect 1. Only available for Trilogy purchasers.
-Bring Down the Sky DLC has to be downloaded separately and installed unlike the description in the store page where it says its available already.

reviewText: The start of what became an epic story. Compared to the next two games in the series, the combat here can feel clunky, and the HUD/Menus aren't as refined, neither are the character models (the screenshot of Shepard in the menu holding the weapons says it all), but the story, the voice acting and the characters themselves are so well done that you almost forget about the rest. The fact that choices you make in this game have an effect on what you experience not only in Mass Effect 2, but 3 as well is amazing.\n\nSeriously, this is a game that I recommend to every sci-fi fan out there because it is simply that good.

reviewText:
Rating 8/10

Overview

Third Person Shooter Role Playing Game  - Impressive game with serious flaws

The Good:

+ The game provides a variety of different classes that suit individual play styles. Each class comes with its own unique set of advantages and disadvantages. Certain classes can only use certain types of weapons and abilities.  The game also gives you the option of solving missions by being good(paragon) or a bit more ruthless (renegade) Depending on your choice, leads to more dialogue options in the future.

+Combat is a huge part of the game. Each gun type feels good, along with the different abilities. You can issue commands to your party members however for the most part they do fine if you leave them be.  Certain battles can be very engaging requiring you to make full use of the environments and equipment.

+The overall plot is excellent and keeps the game interesting. Although it touches upon a lot of different sci fi tropes the game presents all of these ideas in a manner that makes the game interesting and fun to play

+ The writing/dialogue and the voice acting are all fantastic making every interaction engaging to listen to.

+In typical Bioware fashion, the companions and villains are interesting and for the most part, the best characters in the game. Talking to each companion and listening to their history adds a level of depth to the game.

+Character design is excellent, each race has a unique look and feel to them adding to the believability.

+ The main missions are varied and fun to play, each mission involves driving a vehicle which helps break up the shooting segments and keeps things from getting stale.

+The lead up to the final confrontation and ultimately the conclusion is epic. It really feels satisfying, and is a fitting end to the game. I would argue this game has a better build up to the end than the other games in the series.

+The overall scope of this game is impressive for what its trying to accomplish. The game has a variety of different planets to explore in your vehicle, side missions, story missions, talking to your companions, learning the history of the different races, planets, technologies etc. If you are a gamer who loves being absorbed into a universe Bioware did a fantastic job of detailing every possible aspect of the game.

+Graphically the game still holds up very well, though textures seem blurry.

+ Music and sound

The Bad:

- The user interface is abysmal for what this game is trying to accomplish. Buying/Selling or even equipping items in your inventory seems much harder than it needs to be. The UI does not convey information in a presentable fashion. There are options missing that would makes things so much easier, i.e organizing  inventory lists based on damage/accuracy etc.

-Side missions are incredibly repetitive for all the wrong reasons. The game recycles three or 4 level designs over and over again taking the fun out of playing these missions. In addition most side quest missions are completed the same way- Kill lots of enemies, reach the end of the level, talk to somebody and resolve it by being good or bad. If you played one of them, you pretty much played them all.

-The idea of exploring different planets, discovering lost ruins, and missions certainly sounds awesome but something was lost in the execution. Going down to a planet is amazing the first time but quickly wears off its appeal the third, fourth or fifth time. Every planet although very different in look and feel, plays out all the same. Driving around in barren landscapes is only fun for so long. This is the only way to get and complete side quests.

-Bugs, glitches are present. I got stuck in a wall more than a few occasions.

-No official controller support. I know mods exists to correct this issue but it is not fully implemented. You can't properly use the controller in menus nor can you use it when issuing commands to your party members.

Conclusion
There is plenty to love with this game and I certainly loved my time with it, however the glaring flaws holds it back from what should be a true classic.

reviewText: The Mass Effect trilogy is with out a doubt my favourite, as few games have captivated me in such a scale as these ones. This particular game is the first in the trilogy(obviously) and in many ways what got me into the rpg-genre of gaming. I wasn't a fan of this genre beforehand and for me to get my hands on this game was actually a happy mistake. I got to randomly try out the demo and have never looked back since. The greatest strengts of this game is its grand, epic and interesting story, both ingame and lorewise. Bioware(developer) is also known to craft some of the finest characters/companions around, which makes the whole experience that more awesome. You care about them and want to get to know them better for their great diversity, flaws or stengths. Some of the gameplay may be a bit rusty (It came out in 2007) but if you're in for the story and lore you will not get dissapointed. The sequels will greatly expand on the gameplay, as will your choices. Remember, the Mass Effect saga is currently over 3 games and choices made in the first game will haunt you in the second or third installment.

+The lead up to the final confrontation and ultimately the conclusion is epic. It really feels satisfying, and is a fitting end to the game. I would argue this game has a better build up to the end than the other games in the series.

+The overall scope of this game is impressive for what its trying to accomplish. The game has a variety of different planets to explore in your vehicle, side missions, story missions, talking to your companions, learning the history of the different races, planets, technologies etc. If you are a gamer who loves being absorbed into a universe Bioware did a fantastic job of detailing every possible aspect of the game.

+Graphically the game still holds up very well, though textures seem blurry.

+ Music and sound

The Bad:

- The user interface is abysmal for what this game is trying to accomplish. Buying/Selling or even equipping items in your inventory seems much harder than it needs to be. The UI does not convey information in a presentable fashion. There are options missing that would makes things so much easier, i.e organizing  inventory lists based on damage/accuracy etc.

-Side missions are incredibly repetitive for all the wrong reasons. The game recycles three or 4 level designs over and over again taking the fun out of playing these missions. In addition most side quest missions are completed the same way- Kill lots of enemies, reach the end of the level, talk to somebody and resolve it by being good or bad. If you played one of them, you pretty much played them all.

-The idea of exploring different planets, discovering lost ruins, and missions certainly sounds awesome but something was lost in the execution. Going down to a planet is amazing the first time but quickly wears off its appeal the third, fourth or fifth time. Every planet although very different in look and feel, plays out all the same. Driving around in barren landscapes is only fun for so long. This is the only way to get and complete side quests.

-Bugs, glitches are present. I got stuck in a wall more than a few occasions.

-No official controller support. I know mods exists to correct this issue but it is not fully implemented. You can't properly use the controller in menus nor can you use it when issuing commands to your party members.

Conclusion
There is plenty to love with this game and I certainly loved my time with it, however the glaring flaws holds it back from what should be a true classic.

reviewText: 9.8/10 so close to a 10...\nThis is a defining moment in gaming history, and it deserves to be. As a third person shooter alone it's pretty good, but when you combine the RPG elements it becomes truly one of the best games I've ever played. Of course, that's just the start, throw in the epic storyline which really does change as you make decisions, the people you'll meet and places you'll see, and it becomes a genuinely unmissable series. Then import that character into ME2, or replay as a whole new shep.

reviewText:
A milestone in RPG history.

Simply put, Mass Effect is a masterpiece of storytelling. I cant tell you how many times I've replayed this game, and still find new things.
Characters you wish were real are all about you as you take on the role as the titular Commander Shepard.
Music and gameplay are great to. Shooting mechanics are a little bit ropey but I never any issues with it.

If you've never played any of the Mass Effect games, get in on the ground floor and play the original first. I stand as one of the few who actually enjoys the first one just as much as the second, which some call the best RPG of all time.

There is simply no reason for anyone to miss out on this game. 10/10!

reviewText: Basically a spiritual sequel to Star Control 2, with ground combat replacing ship combat. It's obvious that BioWare was heavily inspired by that classic, even though Mass Effect manages to build its own unique and impressive mythos. This game is extremely fun all around, though exploration and interaction with the various extraterrestrial races is perhaps the high point of the entire game. I'm of the opinion that this game would have worked as a standalone title without the sequels that followed it, though the sequels are good in their own right. Regardless, this is worth playing, especially now at such a discounted price. Recommended.

reviewText:
Mass Effect is quite simply my favourite game series. It all started with this first installment which introduces us to an immersive open galaxy where the decisions we make through gameplay and dialogue options shape our journey along throughout our time in the game. You play as a Commander of your own ship and are tasked with bringing a rogue Spectre to justice.

Along the way you visit numerous planets and environments with a squad of team mates you recruit along the way. The character interactions between you and your squad truly shape your experience playing the game as you begin to learn about their backgrounds and understand their motivations for fighting alongside you.

The plot is straightforward with an engaging villain (the rogue Spectre Saren) and develpos at a steady pace with many more options for side quests that help build and shape the world building, or galaxy building I should say.  Playing as Commander Shepard you have the option to play nicely (paragon) or rather roughly (renegade) while dealing with your dialogue wheel options, allowing to to shape your character's personality. I personally prefer the paragon route.

Any downsides I would mention are the somewhat clunky mechanics during fire fights and the difficulty there can sometimes be when you try and fail to take cover. The graphics have aged compared to the more recent installments but  can still be considered decent. I highly reccommend giving the Mass Effect game series a go. It will change your perception of sci-fi RPGs for the better, and not to mention there are two jaw-dropping sequels to sink your teeth into after this one.

reviewText:
There isn't enough positive words to describe my love for the game and it's counter-parts.
TL;DR - Brilliant storyline, immersive galaxy and worlds to visit. The characters and chemistry between you and character you meet are one of the things that makes Mass Effect so great. A truly brilliant RPG for those who love Science Fiction and action games.

As you can tell by the amount of time I've spent playing this game, I've done quite a few playthroughs (I've lost count of how many times I've played Mass Effect, but it's an abnormally large number). Bioware really has a knack of combining a great storyline and character development together with gameplay and customisation. Of course, this was before EA really got them by the balls and milked their franchise dry.

First things first, here is what I LOVED about this game.
- The story (as mentioned many times above) could not be any better;  immediately you're thrown into the story, as Commander Shepard, with the Alliance Navy, on your way to Eden Prime to check out some Prothean artifacts and screw up whatever plan the bad guys had going.  The different plot points blend together perfectly; the introduction of Saren Arterius, the Geth, the Citadel and your Spectre ranking, it all just comes and goes so well. The interaction with characters and potential romance options really puts the player in the game and the experiences really stick with you.
- The lore/canon behind the different points of the game and the background to the game is brilliant; I've spent many hours external of the game reading up on the Mass Effect Wikia page about different planets, key events (like the discovery of the Mass Relay near Pluto) and the technology seen within the game. Players can learn everything and more about the Mass Effect universe without even leaving the game, the codex contains lots and lots of sub-sections pointing to various information about the universe, with the player being able to add more and more accessible canon stories to the codex by interacting with certain items or buildings in game.
- Character customisation is really in-depth and customisable; right off the bat, you are given the choice to edit your character's name, appearance, classification and background story. The appearance customisation options are alright, it's pretty default across a lot of RPG games. The class system is great also, with different classes offering the player different weapon choices, in-game powers and abilities. By selecting a character's background story, it really allows you to set up your characters morals for whatever way you wish to play;  whether you want to be a badass Male/Female Shepard who doesn't ask questions and shoots first, or a negotiator, who can talk their way out of anything , you have those choices in Mass Effect.
- In-game levelling up and point assignment to you and your squadmates works very well; you have lots of options to add points to specific abilites that will become more accurate, powerful or varied with you and your team in combat and in dialogue. You can also access all your squad's character profiles on the Normandy and customise each one individually, as well as assign different squadmates to you with different missions.
- The variety of weapons and mods available is huge to say the least; you can modify any weapon to have different effects on enemies, have a fast fire rate or more accuracy to name a few, as well as purchase or loot newer, more powerful weapons and equip them to you and your squadmates. The same is said for armor and omni-tools, which too can be upgraded by newer items.

Now, for the things I was not so much a fan of in Mass Effect.
- Off the bat I'm going to appeal to any of you graphic predators; this game is not high-end, cutting edge in the graphics department, it's pretty meh for a game that came out in 2007, compare to the likes of Assassin's Creed or Crysis that came out the same year. But available mods can greatly improve in-game textures and such if it really bothers you.
- In-game, the mechanics of combat and everything combat-related is not really that great; the whole cover system, FOV and freeze screen selection is alright, but the newer Mass Effect 2 and 3 definitely improve on this game's mechanics.
- The exploration options in the game are pretty linear, but definitely better than Mass Effect 2 and 3. Every world just kind of looks the same but in different colours or with a few different bases re-arranged. The mako is also a pain in the ♥♥♥ to command around when exploring, getting stuck on mountain sides or in ditches and causing a lot of awkward situations.

To conclude my review of Mass Effect;  this game and it's counter-parts are my pride and joy of video games. The game overall is so well made and the elements of it just work together fantastically, and for   £7.99, I think it's worth every penny   (or wait until the Steam sales, where I've seen it sell for £1.99 many times).
I highly recommend you invest in this game if you like RPGs, Science Fiction or want to play a game you'll get lost in over and over again, for hours on end.

reviewText:
Fantastic. Absolutely incredible. A space-faring action RPG!

I love the crap out of this game. The combat, the weapons, the skill tree, the story, everything. Fabulous. Well done, Bioware.

The story is enthralling, and you really feel like you're fighting to save the galaxy. The twists and turns are delicious and surprising.

The combat system is fantastic. Finally a run-and-gun style of game that doesn't require you to hunt around for tons of freaking ammo. Instead guns have limitless ammo, but you can't fire too much or they'll overheat and be useless for a short time. Really a great mechanic, I love it. Scrounging and searching for ammo while playing was always annoying and immersion breaking for me in other games.

The skill tree is great, very in-depth. You have a lot of choices to make and can make a unique character. I could play this game twenty times twenty different ways and STILL have different paths to take and different characters to create. Well done.

The voice acting is fantastic. Love it.

Overall a wonderful game. 10/10

reviewText: Mass Effect is the first in a series of games where you play as Commander Shepard, the first first mate of the USS Normandy, who is given command of the Normandy after a devestating attack on the human colony of Eden Prime. Your mission is to investigate the alien race behind the attack and save the Galaxy. Without going into anymore detail, as I wouldn't want to ruin it for you. Mass Effect is one of my all time favorite video game series, as the story just draws you in. The characters give you some back story, and you can explore the homeworlds of several council races, as well as explore the galaxy in general with your ship. Choices you make effect the gameplay overall and can be carried from the First Mass Effect into 2 and 3.\n\nThe game is played in third-person mode, has a magnificent story and is visually pleasing to play. The only criticism I have for this does not come against the game itself, but against Steam for not having Mass Effect 3. Due to a deal Bioware made, Steam will never have the rights to Mass Effect 3, which means you won't be able to get the full experience of the series on Steam. With that aside, this game is worth playing if you are a fan of video games.

reviewText: The mass effect series is by far my favorite game series ever.  The first title in the series has sort of wierd combat and a wierd inventory system, but where the first mass effect game excells is the story and character development and introducing the player to the univerese of mass effect to prepare for the other 2 games.  The other 2 games have waaay better gameplay mechanics, but in order to truly delve into one of the most interesting and exciting sci fi stories ever, you have to play this game.

reviewText:
The story was well put together.  I liked the way they did the morality system (separate counters for good and bad).  It allowed me to role-play my character better.  The game was structured in such a way that I felt like my choices actually made a difference.  There were a few times where I had to step away from my computer to collect my thoughts and make a plot decision that I didn't want to screw up.

One thing that really impressed me is that Mass Effect managed to avoid looking dated even though I played it around 5 years after it came out.

I enjoyed the game.  It's quite solid.

reviewText: The start of a landmark series which changed choice based games forever. What can I say about this game? reviewText:
2007 was a golden year for gaming.  With titles like Bioshock and Super Mario Galaxy, it was undoubtedly a great year.  Mass Effect is one of those rare few games that truely capture what an RPG is all about.  Combining fantastic writing, visuals that still hold up to this day, a combat system that was so different yet worked so well, and a giant open world, you have one hell of a game.  RPG elements include skill leveling, tons of different kinds of weapons, abilities that all serve a purpose in the battlefield, and tons of side quests (some goofy, some awesome) that all seem to work so well.  The characters are colorful and the voice acting superb, especially Jennifer Hale's femshep voice.  But remember, humans are not the only species in the galaxy, and aliens play a big part in your adventure, some will help you and some will try to kill you, so its up to you to decide who should pal around at your side.

Of course, with all great things, there are downsides.  The world, as vast as it is, can seem a bit empty at times, and the squad memeber AI can prove to be difficult.  There are a few glitches, but nothing gamebreaking and nothing severely awful.

All in all I reccomend this game to everyone, as it is one hell of a ride from beginning to end.  The truely unfortunate thing is that Mass Effect might have been BioWare's magnum opus, as the 2 sequels fell under the care of EA.  We can only hope BioWare has woken up to try and fix what they destroyed in Mass Effect 4.

I give Mass Effect a 10/10
