reviewText:
Such a good game oh my God. Well written and developing characters, epic story and massive amounts of lore, this is definetly my kind of game.

The combat was, at times, frustrating with my team mates getting in the way from time to time but the option to can organise the tactics of battle is available, if a little messy. In the end the combat was fun and it felt great to blast enemies away with the shotgun thanks to the level ssystemm that allowed me to upgrade any aspect of my Shepard that I wanted.

The strongest aspect of the game for me however, was the extensive dialogue and heavy story line. That's just me but if you don't enjoy cutscenes and/or plenty of talking then this is not for you. I do, so I created my FemShep and together we set off on an epic journey to distant planets with our alien team members. My FemShep also took a shine to a member of a certain mono-gendered species but who your Shepard takes an interest in is up to you~

The shere amount of side quests work well to expand the length of gameplay and without completeling them all, it took me 29 hours to fully finish the game. I heavily recommend it and I'm now drooling over the sequel, I can't wait to get my hands on it.

reviewText:
PROS:

+ Definitely one of the most interesting, yet complex plots out there
+ Gameplay is dynamically shaped by your actions and dialogue selections
+ Can go around as a total ♥♥♥♥, or an ethical and universal role model
+ Epic protagonist
+ Fluid game mechanics
+ Does a decent job getting your emotions a little worked up
+ Viable for replayability
+ Most maps are impressively immersive
+ AI is actually pretty good
+ Different alien species can be fun to learn more about
+ Gives the player the option to play strategically with the eccentric specialties of each squad member
+ Fun side quests, with some being humorous
+ Even after understanding the plot 100%, there are still unresolvable mysteries that leave the players to assume for themselves
+ Awesome voice acting, but Shepard's can start to sound monotone after a while
+ Textures are a little meh, but are enough to keep you immersed
+ Lotsa lens flares
+ Optional and unintrusive romance

CONS:

- Citadel is large and can be too confusing to navigate through
- Too many useless elevators
- Walking/jogging speed is kind of slow
- Inventory system is really annoying to use
- Sound sometimes, but rarely, started acting whacky for me
- Exploring (landing on") planets that are extraneous to the main plot can sometimes be rewarding

reviewText:
A really good action/RPG game in every aspect. The story, voice acting, graphics, sound, music and gameplay are all good.

The game seems like a fusion of Dragon Age, KOToR and Neverwinter Nights all wrapped up together in a wonderful package. If you liked any of those games, you will undoubtedly like this!

You follow the path of Shepard (male or female depending on your preference) in a desperate attempt to save the galaxy from the ominous Reapers. Along the way you recruit companions, fall in love and make tough decisions. It also allows for a little exploration in form of the many sidequests.

You get to select from a multitude of different classes and level-up and outfit the characters however you want. It also features a squad ordering system (although basic) to position your squad tactically. The combat is in the form of an over-the-shoulder third person, cover-based shooter. It works well here when combined with your squads various strengths and weaknesses.

All-in-all, a very good game that I would recommend to everyone interested in the format.

Jimbo Rating: 8/10

reviewText: Mass Effect is a great game - some may criticise the combat but I liked it. It's a brilliant example of what an action-RPG should be in terms of interaction and dialogue. There's plenty of background lore to read through, and it's actually quite interesting. The story is also very good, and there are lots of side-quests to pursue as you explore various systems. Unlike other games, there are actual consequences in Mass Effect and your actions can and will decide who lives and who dies.\n\nThe use of elevators is also a key gameplay mechanic that I find adds a lot to the game.

reviewText:
I just finished beating this game, I'm a little late to get into this series I think, but regardless, I bought it and played it.

And well I can honestly say I don't regret a dollar or a minute spent on this. This game is just awesome.

Where do I start...

First of all the game looks pretty good, even if its a bit older. I don't have a computer that can play on the highest settings honestly, but I still found it enjoyable and looked pretty clean to me. Regardless I don't really care that much to be honest ;p

Oh and the combat is pretty enjoyable I find. Its a shooter type of combat basically, but with a few RPG elements to the combat, I find it quite enjoyable personally, the number of ablities are not overly abundant, but I'm ok with that. I find it doesn't bother me a ton. The combat was also pretty well made so that you, in most cases, can't just go in the middle of the fight, and you actually have to take cover and stuff. It was pretty decently challanging at times and I was playing on the normal difficulty or default one or whatever. Maybe I just suck, idk ;p. But it typically doesn't feel to easy.

The part about the game that is arguably the best however is the story, and the interacting with characters, its hard to pick one, but they sort of go hand in hand to an extent.

I won't spoil the story to those who haven't played, but I found it very good, it felt like I was watching a movie and I was always curious as to what would happen next, or in the future.

As for the interaction with other characters, especially squad members, it is just very interesting. In talking to the different crew members you learn more about them, and sometimes about different species, and you even learn about other background information and their personal thoughts on things. Not to mention sometimes get missions. You can also romance with any squad member of the opposite gender if you so choose ;p.

Oh and you can loose squad members(I lost two in my playthrough) which sounds bad, but it only happens through story events. Some are unpreventable to my knowledge, and they lead to some hard choices, which can really play with your emotions and make you feel guilty.

Overall the game does a great job of getting you attached(Or to hate) the different characters, and that is just really enjoyable.

However the game isn't without its flaws. First of all the game I noticed had a fair number of bugs, some minor, others frusterating, and some making it so I had to reload the game. I only encountered maybe 5 in my whole playthrough, but I think 3 of them involved me falling through the world and having to reload the game, which was frustating at times.

There is also a weird black siloute bug that apparently involves AMD processors or something, look it up, I did and apparently others with AMD processors and stuff have similar issues, not unplayable with it, and it only occurs in like two different worlds in the main story, but it can be a bit annoying.

Another thing I noticed is that atleast concerning the classes that don't specialize in using the sniper there is no scope, its like a blind fire weapon basically and totally useless. Of course I haven't played anything besides sentinel, so it could be different on them.

Frankly the weapons besides the pistol that I had a specialization in on my class where kinda useless I found and I never used any much besides the pistol and sometimes the shotgun, but thats really not that big of a deal, the sniper ones really the biggest issue concerning the weapons.

Overall the game is great, it has me hooked after playing through it once, and contemplating playing again, so i'd say its well worth it. I'm going to go after the next games in the series as soon as I can.

reviewText:
So I found Mass Effect on a Steam Sale back in 2013, and purchased it for hardly anything. I'd not read any reviews on the game, so had no idea what to expect once I bought it. I guess, truth be told, I only bought it because it was so cheap and I hoped it could fill a few hours one boring evening after work. Oh, sweet Mass Effect, you didn't disappoint!

There aren't many games that I genuinely wish I could remove from my memory, in order to replay again with a fresh set of eyes, but the exceptional story of Mass Effect, combined with the excellent character acting, life and death decisions that you'll face, and Shepherd's development and rise from traumatised soldier to first human Spectre, is a real work of genius.

Despite this game being made in 2008 (I think), I only started playing it in March 2014. In total, I've spent around 43 blissfully happy hours running through the main story and side quests (excluding those pesky 'collect so many of this type of tag' quests). I know many games don't age well, but Mass Effect doesn't look old, nor dated, and if I didn't know the age of this game, I'd quite truthfully believe it was new and current.

I'll close by saying that anyone not already familiar with Mass Effect should buy it immediately - well, if you like story driven games, of course. If not, just wait for a Steam Sale and buy it when it's virtually free!

Now, enough singing the praises of Mass Effect - I was also fortunate enough to buy Mass Effect 2 in the same sale. I just hope it lives up to my lofty expectations and doesn't lose the excitement built from this true classic!

reviewText:
Pros:
-Story. This isn't surprising. Bioware games tend to be very plot-heavy and less centered on action. More talky-talky bits and extreme decision making. Less shooty-killy.
The downside is that while you get a good chunk of the story in the beginning, it doesn't really pick up fully until over halfway through the game.
Don't get me wrong. When it picks up, it really picks you up and throws you over the table and repeatedly screws you.

-Decisions. Like in Dragon Age, the choices you make do effect the rest of the gameplay and subsequent events. Impacting in the next two games for the trilogy, though I've yet to play 'em.

-Action. My first rpg shooter. I like that it wasn't so centered on kill-kill-kill. It allowed me time to get into it, and I'm not big on shooters. This doesn't feel like it's utterly in my face. It's third-person shooter, so I think that helps.

-Controls. Very easy to get used to.

-Gameplay. Very few timed events.


Cons:

-Controls. Yes, this is a pro, but in a few cases, it's a con. And it's only a con when you're in a vehicle called the Mako. Mass Effect was a game designed for the console, not the PC. And it shows. Holy hell, does it show.
My driving is akin to a drunkard on speed. I managed to flip the damn car over when gravity was on MY side. Every death I suffered was due to that damn car. And you need to use that car a lot. It kills a lot of the fun within the game. Thankfully, it's not essential to the overall game, and if you're not a completionist, you won't have to use it that often.

-The 'lockpicking'. It took me forever to figure out wtf I was supposed to do. The game offers you no direction on that. And in decrypting something, the codes are a bit iffy as opposed to how it is for the xbox or PS3. It's a pain in the ♥♥♥. Once you learn what the hell to do, it's pretty simple. But until you figure it out, it's just banging your head against the wall.

-Characters need more by way of development. What was there was definitely touching, and I'm in NO way saying that these characters aren't awesome in their own right. I was touched by a few of their stories. But perhaps I'm spoiled by DA, and Bioware is pretty known for their character development, interactions, etc.

-Romances. One male romance for a female main character. One female romance for a male main character. And one female romance for either gender main character.

Though I'll give it points for having the bisexual love interest be an alien.

Awesome points:

-The aliens. Lots of variations, and I really like 'em all. Humans are pretty much on the lower rung here. There are prejudices, other alien races don't much care for humans and humans are the minorities. There's a small group of humans that are all Human Pride sort of thing, but they're largely irrelevant.

-The Reapers. I don't want to give any spoilers here, but these are seriously such a badass group of villains. The game made them genuinely scary.

-The planets. This probably won't mean much to those who don't care about lore or anything like that, but I found the short summarizations on the different planets to be pretty damn cool and innovative.


The Ugly:

-The profiles. You cannot make a pretty male Shepherd or a pretty female Shepherd. The textures, lights, shadows, angles will make even the most meticulously done Shepherd fugly. It's highly annoying.

-This is one of those games in which it's hard to figure out the first time you play it. Not controls-wise, but everything else-wise. Where to go, what to see, etc. Largely because this world is so big. It's a solar system and it FEELS like a solar system.
However, once you've completed one playthrough, you won't really need a guide anymore. It helps that it's a pretty short game. It could probably be played through in the course of a weekend.

reviewText:
I'm recamending this game because of all the Sci-Fi adventure games this one is at the top; it really captures the feeling of Star Trek, a feeling utterly missed by every Star Trek game.

But with that said, this game is far from perfect, mostly because it is faced with some massive annoyances:
-Unskippable and unpausable cut scenes
-A terrible autosave system
-Boss's that are just enemies with a massive health bar
-Broken Quick Save System


These may not sound like little problems, but lets look at what they all cause. OK lets say you die, not that rare, there are a lot of enemies that can 1 to 2 hit you if you can't see them, this means you are relying on the last save point, but since the environments are so big that means the last auto save could be 30mins ago. ALSO, if there are any cutscenes that occur your going to have to go through them again because unlike 99% of all other games that would autosave your progress after a cutscene, in this game thats not the case. BUT wait there is quick saving right? Wellllll, quick saving only works if there are no enemies, so if there is a string of enemies a long a 30 min trek you are ♥♥♥♥ out of luck my friend. The game should keep track of 3 quick saves and allow you to quick save at any point that, that way i don't need to repeat the same 45 mins of my life over again like some lamer version of Groundhogs Day and if I quick save a death by accident I could use the previous quick save. Also, the last boss is a measure of your patients as he is health bar Mcgee, not hard, just repetative and boring.

Overall Its a good game, I just wise it didn't make me feel like I was getting in the way of it's story all the time.

reviewText: Bioware really came into their own for me with this one; gone is the tedium of half-rate D&D-style grindfests. Instead, you find yourself at the helm of a shooter action RPG, roaming the galaxy to recruit crew members and fight for survival. While most of the planet sequences were a bit tedious (especially if you feel the need for completion), the game flows smoothly and you'll be hard-pressed to find anything else like it. This game set the bar for a whole new style of cinematic gameplay.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game for anyone who is interested in a FPS game with a rich story.

You can explore the milky way galaxy with many solar systems, all having their own planets. The main storyline is engaging and fun, and the side quests are meaningful and often change the dialogue you can exchange with other characters. The romantic subplots are also very interesting and allow insight into the background of your characters. The option to play as a Paragon or a Renegade based on the qualities of your actions is also a nice dynamic allowing moral feedback for your character.

All in all, one of the best games I have ever played and definitely has a high replay value.

reviewText:
One of the best modern story-driven RPG's I've ever played. I have no complaints about ME1. I loved every minute of my 2 playthroughs. On my 5yr old PC there were no graphic glitches, no lag or issues of any kind. Just smooth sailing graphics & a wonderful story. The characters are well-written, even the ones you don't like (looking at you Ashley). As in KOTOR, you can go Light or Dark, good or bad, making Dialog choices to reflect your own personality or how you want Commander Shepard to be perceived. In this game at least, your choices don't really affect the endgame outcome. Your choices DO open up different dialog options and some side quests. It adds fun flavor to the game.

I loved finding all the armor & weps scattered around everywhere you go. I liked the hacking puzzle mini-game to open caches. It reminded me of the similar hydraulic puzzle game in Bioshock, which I also loved - both the main game & the mini puzzle game.

The DLC is FreeAnother plus for ME1 is the 2 DLC's are free & easily found to download. Some nice people have already linked them in other helpful reviews, or just Google.

Common ComplaintsThe Mako
Some people complain about the Mako, which if you haven't played the game yet, is a tank-like vehicle you drive when you explore planets. I personally loved driving the crazy thing. Yes, it can be hard to control. Things can get a little wild, but it's really not that hard & once you get the hang of it, driving it literally anywhere is good fun. Mostly though, combat in the thing with its cannon & gun are a literal blast.

Exploration
Some people complained about exploring Planets. I personally enjoyed this aspect as well. You only explore at most, 1 planet per system, & exploring each planet only takes a few minutes. Of course, I did really like driving the Mako so any excuse to get in the thing & go nuts was welcome.

Game Won't Start, or get a Black or White Screen then game won't start
This did actually happen to me once, but is VERY simple to fix. Find the game's .exe, right click it and select Open as Administrator". If that doesn't work for you
hoursPlayed: THEN rt click ME1's .exe to "Open As". You should only ever have to do this once
voteText:
then done. It happened to me at about 5hours in. I was frustrated for about 10 minutes before I found this simple solution. After that I just started the game normally for the rest of my playtime.



Other Similar Games I recommend you play:
Dragon Age Series
Mass Effect Series
KOTOR Series
Bioshock Series - Especially 1
helpfulPercent:
2 & Minerva's Den DLC (Excellent standalone story there)

All of those game titles are equal in my esteem. They all provide good value for the price & all have a great story. These games all really draw you in. IMO you just can't go wrong with any of them.

reviewText:
Everyone told me that I wouldn't love all of BioWare's games, but there would be one series that resonates with me indefinitely, and that was Mass Effect.

ME brought to me a host of things I have never seen in a game before: an active, beautiful storyline full of wonderful lore (via the codex) that not only made me very intimate with what was going on, but also impacted how I played the game. A story where your decisions actually impact how the story progresses.

The graphics certainly weren't anything to shake a stick at. They were solid for the time period, but definitely not anything mind blowing. The music was wonderful, with plenty of jams that I enjoyed along the way.

The gameplay is what truly stood out to me. I'm not a big fan of shooters, but this game allowed me to appreciate them. Tie in some RPG elements to anything and I'll be willing to give it a go. The vast planets that you can explore and the isolation of some of them really made you feel like you were a part of a universe that was very real.

I don't have enough good words to say about ME. If you've never played it at all, I urge you to pick it up and give it a go, no matter what kind of a gamer you classify yourself as.

reviewText:
After bunches of strangers posted to me about Mass Effect, I finally gave it a go. Space-themed game with focus on story? Sounds right up my alley.

Right away, I need to criticize the main city of the game, the Citadel. Who in the world designed this mess? I'm not saying it's fugly. In fact, it looks quite nice. It's just that it's poorly laid out and needlessly labyrinthine... especially for a main hub of the game.

The shooter aspect was okay. I'm not really a first or third person shooter type, but it worked, and it was playable, so I'll leave it at that.

I'm still not exactly sure what the point of scanning planets for resources was. It was hardly crucial to the plot or gameplay. Just a pure homage to Star Control?

Replay value is... there. I admit I would have liked to go back and earn some achievements that provide rewards, but the gameplay just wasn't enticing enough to me to warrant a second playthrough. I need to note that playing as a Paragon is boring as hell. I recommend trying out a Renegade to bring out the more interesting conversations.

The game has excellent atmosphere, and some pretty interesting alien backstory. I don't quite understand the trend of cramming in bucketloads of irrelevant information in the in-game encyclopedia, but I guess there's an audience for it. The strength of the game I feel is in the character conversations, but those weren't as frequent as I would have liked.

Overall I'd have to say I wasn't disappointed. I wasn't blown away by the plot, though that's my fault for setting a high expectation. The main story isn't the kind of story that makes you a better person for having experienced it, but it was interesting nonetheless, especially towards the end. Still not Planescape: Torment caliber. 8.5/10

reviewText:
I was struggled for a very long time if I should buy this game or not.
I regret that I didn't buy it sooner.

It is one of the Top 10 best games I have played. The gameplay might be a bit monotonus, but rewarding items, the story and your possible decisions make up for it.

When I first played it I was AMAZED by how well every detail is described. Why the machines and weapons work and what they do. What every alien species backstory is and why they behave like they behave.
It's a whole new universe to discover. I haven't seen any game before that cared so much about filling every logical hole and describing so much details, expanding the story to such great amounts. Awesome!

Also, if you're a fan of astronomy, you'll love it so much more. Enjoy the most epic views of standing on a planets moon, being on a planet of a binary star system, or watch thousands of meteors raining down from the sky.
As a fan of science, you might notice some physical details which aren't correct as they are. Like planets temperature described as going below the point of absolute zero (-273,18°C is not possible), our local sun shining yellow in space, or other little details. Nothing what would involve gameplay or bother you in some way.

All in all, great game. I love it, I am a fan of the Mass Effect Universe now.

reviewText:
Mass Effect is probably one of my most played games to date (just behind Mass Effect 2).

Although I believe Mass Effect 2 is the superior of the two games in question (1 and 2), this is where the journey began - and should begin for you. I would (and do) highly recommend the Mass Effect Trilogy to anyone who finds themselves enthralled with single player experiences and Mass Effect is one of the best you can find.

I am currently on my second playthough of the Mass Effect Trilogy and I'm sure when I'm finished I will jump straight back in to Mass Effect 1 again.

Mass Effect follows what I like to call the constants and variables" theory of storytelling. This means that the story has a few key sections that all players will experience
date: yet the road there can be different from person-to-person. Moreover
recommended: the types of decisions you make can also affect the outcome these "constant" events. The main decision elements come from your ability to either take a Paragon (good) or a Renegade (somewhat evil
hoursPlayed: more of a ♥♥♥♥ really) approach to decision making
voteText: earning points through doing so allows you to automatically open up more conversation options to enhance your experience.\n\nI personally feel that Mass Effect has pretty good character customisation - with not just how they look
helpfulPercent: but how you lay out your play style for the rest of the game. Being an infiltrator allows you to snip enemies from afar to deal a lot of damage. Whereas
votesHelpful: you have a soldier who is a master of all weapons and usually likes to be in the thick of the action. The same can also be said of a Vanguard
votesTotal: they mix the world of Biotics (like superpowers) and guns together.\n\nThe only downside to Mass Effect 1 is the glitches that can occur (and usually do for me)
votesFunny: but a quick google of fixes usually resolves the issue. The hacking system is also only a minor gripe at what is one of my favourite games.\n\nIn conclusion
commentsCount: the positives of Mass Effect extremely out weight the negatives.\n\n9/10 from me (because it's not Mass Effect 2)"

reviewText:
Mass Effect is a role-playing shooter in a beautifully realized sci-fi world. It was the second-to-last game made by the – legendary – game studio Bioware, before the inevitable quality decline set in, that occurs when a studio is incorporated into the EA roster.

Even though Mass Effect was originally an Xbox 360 exclusive, Bioware did not let the limited hardware hinder the game's potential. The game was a visual masterpiece, and the tight movement and combat naturally inherited from the Unreal Engine played wonderfully into the game's core shooting mechanics. The intense firefights with lasers, explosions, and kinetic powers, kept you at the edge of your seat – but it was the expansive universe, and heavy story elements, that kept you from leaving it.

If I were to make a parallel between another much beloved piece of media, I'd say that Mass Effect followed the Matrix formula to a T. Much akin to the Matrix trilogy, the first part of the Mass Effect trilogy is an independent piece that stands on its own, it builds up a mysterious and interesting world, and let's you take it in however much you like – but just like the Matrix trilogy, the second and third parts thoroughly disappoint.

Why The Matrix trilogy went the way it did is a mystery only the Wachowskis can answer for, but as for Mass Effect, we can clearly point our fingers at EA and say: “They did it!”. Mass Effect, along with Dragon Age: Origins, were Bioware's final games that showed the brilliance of the studio. The games that followed are little more than fan-service on top of bad writing. Let's not even start with The Old Republic.

As for Mass Effect, it's one of the most fleshed out worlds ever created. The game hooks you from the start, and won't let go – even when the credits roll. You're gonna wanna go back, and it's recommended, as the game has twists and turns that will only reveal themselves on second or third playthroughs.

I recommend this game to anyone and everyone.

reviewText:
Mass Effect is a story-rich FPS where you play as Shepard, in a time where the universe is starting to realise the potential of the human species in taking up bigger responsibilities alongside others. Initially under Captain Anderson's command, you are tasked to investigate a distress signal on a planet and during which, you discover that a trusted ally is setting something shady into motion. Throughout the game. you hunt him down and discover the secrets that would have implications on everyone in the known universe.

The game focuses strongly on the story, during which you would have to make a number of decisions that although may not change the story itself, they translate to your character stats, and also the (remaining) crew that you fight with. (And also your sex life lmao.) The combat system is pretty good in that you fight in a section of 3, where your crew could provide interesting powers or just be meat shields as you recharge your own powerups. However, some hostiles such as snipers or rocket turrets could possibly one-shot Shepard and you would have to restart from where the game last saved. Hence, I do recommend that you consistently manual save or you might have to replay a large part of the mission.

I find the game very well-rounded and enjoyable, back by an interesting story. However, one major set back to the action for me would be the extremely long elevator rides. Seems silly but you would have to play it to understand the agony :)

9.5/10

reviewText:
Great game. If you like RPGs, then you'll love this game. I only played ME3 before I played any other Mass Effect games, and this one has proved why its a must have in only 8 hours of play.

Pros:
-Runs well on my system (i5 3570k GTX 770) its a 6 year old game so I think I'd be right to assume that it should rune fine on most systems
-has extensive dialogue options
-Interesting plot
-Good graphics for the time
-Characters are interesting
-The ambiance of locations really make the game feel alive! For example, the Citadel.
-The gameplay is fun, and not very conky
-I find that the cover system is a lot more advanced than the ones that are offered in other AAA games released today, its pretty adaptive.
Cons:
-The inventory system isn't all that great
-Sometimes there's a bit of screen tearing
-If you don't like RPGs and don't really care much about lore and are looking for an fps, then this game won't really stand out for you.

Overall, its a great game, and it never hurts to pick it up on a sale and try it. You will most probably enjoy it!
9.5/10

reviewText:
What can I say about Mass Effect? It is one of my all-time favorite games. The story is really good and the replay value is high due to the fact that you can create different characters focusing on different abilities. Want to be a soldier with all the toys of destruction or a full biotic with limited weapons, or a technician. You can play a character as these types and some in between.

One of the greatest things about the Mass Effect trilogy is that you can import a completed game character into the next installment of the franchise and get bonuses for completing the last installment and pick your character up where you left off. You of course can always just start a new character as well, but it is the carryover of the character that makes the series really unique.

The only strikes against it is some of the tedium related to exploring planets and inventory wrangling.

Definitely a must buy.

reviewText: The game that started one of the biggest sci-fi adventures in gaming history. It's got everything required to make it a classic; interesting and fun characters with unique cultures,  philospohical questions and moral dilemmas, all wrapped around a well-paced and intriguing story (in my opinion the best in the series). It is a wonderful universe that is really easy to get into, though there are a couple of hurdles that really need to be overcome to get a truly great experience out of this. Throughout a lot of the game, characters will spend a LOT of time explaining things to you, like how cultures work and such.  The story, as I mentioned earlier is great, but the gameplay is not. Combat is fairly clunky, cover system is awkward, every gun feels the same, a lot of enemies are braindead and just run up to you with no regard for their own personal safety. Not exactly the highlight of the game, to put it mildly. The Mako, the vehicle which you use for explo-ration as well as a lot of missions, isn't much better either. It's awkward, handles very poorly and is very boring in use for combat, it's generally used for padding outgame length.\n\nStill, it is all in all an amazing game, and gets a 9.1/10 from me.

reviewText:
Mass Effect series are some of my personal favorite games. In Mass Effect there is a good storyline, decent action gameplay, great characters, and an amazing sci-fi universe to discover. The main reason I liked this game was the epic story that takes place (well, more like is started) and the choices that you make within that story.

Pros
-cool sci-fi setting

-decent 3rd person shooter
-ability to make tons of choices
-choices that are made in this game effect the next two games in the series

Cons
-not the best graphics (but hey, it was made in 2007)
-sometimes frustrating to deal with equipment and item upgrades

(9/10)

reviewText:
I'm recamending this game because of all the Sci-Fi adventure games this one is at the top; it really captures the feeling of Star Trek, a feeling utterly missed by every Star Trek game.

But with that said, this game is far from perfect, mostly because it is faced with some massive annoyances:
-Unskippable and unpausable cut scenes
-A terrible autosave system
-Boss's that are just enemies with a massive health bar
-Broken Quick Save System


These may not sound like little problems, but lets look at what they all cause. OK lets say you die, not that rare, there are a lot of enemies that can 1 to 2 hit you if you can't see them, this means you are relying on the last save point, but since the environments are so big that means the last auto save could be 30mins ago. ALSO, if there are any cutscenes that occur your going to have to go through them again because unlike 99% of all other games that would autosave your progress after a cutscene, in this game thats not the case. BUT wait there is quick saving right? Wellllll, quick saving only works if there are no enemies, so if there is a string of enemies a long a 30 min trek you are ♥♥♥♥ out of luck my friend. The game should keep track of 3 quick saves and allow you to quick save at any point that, that way i don't need to repeat the same 45 mins of my life over again like some lamer version of Groundhogs Day and if I quick save a death by accident I could use the previous quick save. Also, the last boss is a measure of your patients as he is health bar Mcgee, not hard, just repetative and boring.

Overall Its a good game, I just wise it didn't make me feel like I was getting in the way of it's story all the time.

reviewText:
The first two times I played this game, it was on the lowly XBox 360.  The game was already very dated five years ago, or so it seemed.  My third playthrough, and my first on the PC, and I'm seeing stunning visuals and textures that were simply not present on the console version.  The game looks worlds better than I remember.  Controls are better (except for the vehicle), and it helps to have a deep understanding of game mechanics from playing all three multiple times through.  My first playthrough of this game was frustratingly difficult because I didn't understand what type of character I had picked or how to properly use the powers.  I suggest a revisit to this game for anyone who liked this series.

Tip:  If anyone's having trouble running this game, or using Steam overlay while playing, close Steam, and reopen it as Administrator.  The games will inherit the permissions, and everything will work fine.

Tip 2:  For anyone having trouble with resolution settings, dig into the Steam game folder for Mass Effect.  There's a launcher in there that lets you change settings, including increasing resolution (for me, 2560 x 1600, but anything 16:10 will need to be set via this launcher to look correct, because the game will only show 16:9 resolutions while looking at in-game settings.)

reviewText:
Epic voice acting.  Smart science.  Rich and developed world.  deep decision options.  Compelling and engaging characters.  This is the first installment of a near legendary game series.  The only weakness for this game in the line in particular is the almost necessary micro management of your inventory.  That is easily tolerable to set up a solid profile to carry through rest of the games.  If you have any enjoyment of story driven games you owe it to yourself to pick it up.

My one genuine con:  Mass Effect 3 is not available on Steam.  Not cool EA.

9/10

reviewText:
This game sets up a very rich and deep universe with lots of unique dialogue and text (logs) to read which make the game feel a LOT bigger than it actually is. The main story in the sequels might be longer and intense but they don't evoke the feeling of being in a massive universe like this one does.

Gameplay wise, it's a bit lacking to be honest - the dialogue choices can be really misleading at times, the combat hasn't aged well and the levels feel a bit sterile or even stale (ex. planetary exploration) at times. Mass Effect 2 might have fixed these issues but at the cost of the more deeper RPG elements of this one.

The sense of scale and all the little story elements that are hidden in Mass Effect make it a great game, well worth replaying even a few years after release, even knowing it all amounts to nothing (ME3)

reviewText:
After 3 years of owning this game I finally buckled down and finished it, and man am i glad i did. I was initally hooked by the tight gameplay. This is a very story focused game so the majority of gameplay is very well designed dialogue trees punctuated by cover shooting. The dialogue trees a very intuitive: options that lead to exposition tend to be on the left and  and story advancing, and affecting choices tend to be on the right. The shooting mechanics are pretty simple, but passably enjoyable with the inclusion of biotic powers to add some stratagy to shake things up a bit.

As for the story of the game it is fantastic. The setting is a galactic community very reminicent of Star Wars with engaging intergalactic politics reminicent of the best of Star Trek & Babylon 5. In short an amazing sci-fi universe. What i like most in a story is the characters, and Mass Effect has some fantastic characters. My favorites being Liara, Garrus, Wrex, Joker, Captain Anderson, Tali'Zora, and of course Wrex. You may have noticed I just listed most of the potental party members and some of the side characters that is how likable and well written Mass Effect's characters are.

Long story short if you are at all a fan of RPGs (this is one of the best i felt fully immersed in the role I was playing), Sci-Fi (the game's universe is the perfect amalgamation of the best of popular Sci-Fi), or even simply great storytelling: Mass Effect comes highly reccommended from me.

reviewText:
What can I say about Mass Effect? It is one of my all-time favorite games. The story is really good and the replay value is high due to the fact that you can create different characters focusing on different abilities. Want to be a soldier with all the toys of destruction or a full biotic with limited weapons, or a technician. You can play a character as these types and some in between.

One of the greatest things about the Mass Effect trilogy is that you can import a completed game character into the next installment of the franchise and get bonuses for completing the last installment and pick your character up where you left off. You of course can always just start a new character as well, but it is the carryover of the character that makes the series really unique.

The only strikes against it is some of the tedium related to exploring planets and inventory wrangling.

Definitely a must buy.

reviewText:
So I found Mass Effect on a Steam Sale back in 2013, and purchased it for hardly anything. I'd not read any reviews on the game, so had no idea what to expect once I bought it. I guess, truth be told, I only bought it because it was so cheap and I hoped it could fill a few hours one boring evening after work. Oh, sweet Mass Effect, you didn't disappoint!

There aren't many games that I genuinely wish I could remove from my memory, in order to replay again with a fresh set of eyes, but the exceptional story of Mass Effect, combined with the excellent character acting, life and death decisions that you'll face, and Shepherd's development and rise from traumatised soldier to first human Spectre, is a real work of genius.

Despite this game being made in 2008 (I think), I only started playing it in March 2014. In total, I've spent around 43 blissfully happy hours running through the main story and side quests (excluding those pesky 'collect so many of this type of tag' quests). I know many games don't age well, but Mass Effect doesn't look old, nor dated, and if I didn't know the age of this game, I'd quite truthfully believe it was new and current.

I'll close by saying that anyone not already familiar with Mass Effect should buy it immediately - well, if you like story driven games, of course. If not, just wait for a Steam Sale and buy it when it's virtually free!

Now, enough singing the praises of Mass Effect - I was also fortunate enough to buy Mass Effect 2 in the same sale. I just hope it lives up to my lofty expectations and doesn't lose the excitement built from this true classic!

reviewText: Mass Effect is a game that is synonymous with quality. A role playing game set in a future of interstellar space travel, Mass Effect makes effective use of player choices and a lawful/chaotic alignment system all balanced with a class-based third person shooter combat system.The storytelling in the game is top notch  with memorable characters and many instances where player choice has a huge effect on the story's outcome. Many of these choice are also carried over into the sequel Mass Effect 2 as well as Mass Effect 3. It's rare that a game is conceived as a trilogy and even rarer when it turns out to be a masterpiece. If you've not played this game yet, you owe it to yourself to do so!

reviewText: For any gamer out there, Mass Effect is a must play.  This game is a third-person, role playing, story-driven shooter and it successfully accomplishes all it sets out to be.  The main storyline clocks in at around 13 hours but the game is packed with other missions and planets to explore on your own time.  Throughout the exploration and firefights, you will surely become attached to certain characters, so decisions you'll have to make later will put you in a cold sweat.  Shooting mechanics in this game are solid, but sometimes feel lacking.  As for the leveling system, not all the skill points you earn feel as if they've gone to any use since there is such a large array of skills and plenty of point slots necessary to fill so as to reach the next power.  All in all, this game is highly recommended to anyone looking for a fantastic single player game.

reviewText:
The first two times I played this game, it was on the lowly XBox 360.  The game was already very dated five years ago, or so it seemed.  My third playthrough, and my first on the PC, and I'm seeing stunning visuals and textures that were simply not present on the console version.  The game looks worlds better than I remember.  Controls are better (except for the vehicle), and it helps to have a deep understanding of game mechanics from playing all three multiple times through.  My first playthrough of this game was frustratingly difficult because I didn't understand what type of character I had picked or how to properly use the powers.  I suggest a revisit to this game for anyone who liked this series.

Tip:  If anyone's having trouble running this game, or using Steam overlay while playing, close Steam, and reopen it as Administrator.  The games will inherit the permissions, and everything will work fine.

Tip 2:  For anyone having trouble with resolution settings, dig into the Steam game folder for Mass Effect.  There's a launcher in there that lets you change settings, including increasing resolution (for me, 2560 x 1600, but anything 16:10 will need to be set via this launcher to look correct, because the game will only show 16:9 resolutions while looking at in-game settings.)

reviewText:
Epic voice acting.  Smart science.  Rich and developed world.  deep decision options.  Compelling and engaging characters.  This is the first installment of a near legendary game series. 9/10

reviewText:
What can I say about this game that already hasn't been said?

I'll try and do this game justice with what I'm about to write.

The story is brilliant and sets up the rest of the following games very well. Your choices matter and will affect the end result further down the line.
Character development is strong. With Garrus being my favourite team member. Seriously, that Turian is awesome. Male Shepard and Garrus are the best bromance I've ever seen in a game.
The RPG elements are in depth and gives you the opportunity to mould your character in any way you want.
The combat is slightly lacklustre, but it can be forgiven and doesn't detract from the core game.

One main negative that a lot of people didn't like was the Mako. Sure it was ungainly and could almost climb near vertical cliffs. But I rather enjoyed the exploration it opened up for you.
You could travel to a planet, land on it and search locations noted on your map. Most of these locations didn't add anything to the main story line, but for me it brought me into the world more, it added lore and detail to the world.

Mass Effect is starting to look slightly outdated these days, though that is a given considering that it's over 8 years old from its first release date.

Buy this game, just for the fact that it'll suck you in and prepare you for the awesome ride that is Mass Effect 2 and most of 3. (I won't go into the details of 3 here, but I'm sure most people know of what I'm on about).

It is single handedly the worse vehicle i have ever drove in a game. When i was on the second last level, it was bounceing off walls, Barely going in a straight line, it was so bad i couldnt even get to the conduit. GEUSS WHAT I HAD TO REDO THAT WHOLE SECTION (even though the mako controlled better, I was still extremely frusterated). In Noveria (peak 15) And the second last level, Geuss what? Shepard and his crew, and most of the enemys were all black textures This completely ruined the atmosphere for me. The negatives are very negative. But the postives are extremely postive. The story is great, Very morbid, And at times inspirational. I suggest you level up your Charm/Intimadation levels because they are very handy. And if you dont have them you have no choice but making regretable decisions.This game is epic, and the sequels are ten times better. The choice making is great, Interaction is great. Fighting is okay. A.i is okay (depends on what difficulty i would assume) Is it worth 20 dollars? Probably not. it hasnt aged that well, i would say pick it up if its on sale, thats what i did. I love this game even if it frusterated me at times. just beware this game isnt perfect.

In conclusion. eh

reviewText:
Summary: A great sci-fi RPG with fun dialogue and action.  It's a bit rough around the edges, but does not disappoint despite its age.

+It's an epic space adventure, in which you save the galaxy!
+Did the above sound awfully generic?  Well, I was surprised at the effort they put into creating a whole new universe with numerous alien races and technologies.  They even put this optional but very cool information in a codex whenever you interact with objects or people.
+A diverse cast of crew members with cool backstories, They even talk to each other when you ride the elevator (and thank gods for that)!
+Combat is generally fun.  Mostly with guns, as well as whatever technological or biotic (mass manipulating) skills you decide to learn.  You can also pause at any time to give orders to your party members.
+The morality" tree isn't clear-cut good/evil
date: but renegade/paragon.  So your lawful actions don't cancel out your chaotic ones
recommended: or vice versa.  Instead each contributes to their own separate bar
hoursPlayed: which enables more dialogue options in the future should you invest the skill points.\n+For the most part
voteText: you're free to do missions (both the main story and side missions) in any order you choose
helpfulPercent:
flying around on your awesome spaceship

-The character movement can be clumsy.  I've gotten killed more than once when Shepard decides he can "take cover" behind a tiny piece of debris.
-Vehicular controls are extremely clumsy.  ♥♥♥♥ driving on hilly terrain
votesHelpful: especially.\n-Side missions can be pretty repetitive after a while
votesTotal: especially since ~70% of them involve driving around planets that are reskinned versions of each other to get to buildings whose layouts are also copies of each other.\n-Inventory size limit is not a huge problem
votesFunny: but still a hassle.  Why did they bother?\n-What the other reviewers said about elevators is true.  There's too many of them and take too freakin' long!"

reviewText: Mass Effect is not a sandbox/open-world RPG.  This game is not about shooting things because you can.  This game, is above that.  This game plays a psychological role in your life, depending on whether you allow it to or not.  If it is to be held as an open-world RPG, let the world be the minds of each person you meet, whether for the first time or the last.  Personally, I believe this is more of an RPG than TES or Fallout, as the role you play shows an impact on the world around you, and the decisions you make can decide whether or not you live as a role-model of humanity or a menace that holds importance.

reviewText:
In my opinion this game is the best of the Series, because it's the least streamlined one with the most choices and freedom of play and with the least amount of completely linear nerfhearding tunnelmaps. The combat in ME3 is better, but the cost is too high.

Pro:

+ Lots of different guns and armor with a ton of different mods. Lots of useless ones too.
+ Lots of dialogue and very few cutscenes.
+ Pretty funny dialogue choices at times, especially the Renegade options can be pretty funny and abusive.
+ Big square planet maps & the Mako. The only game in the ME series with a tactical choice.
+ Experience points for Kills. Time to go hunting for Thresher Maws & Geth!
+ Unlimited ammo, but with overheating and recoil. Nice diversity of guns and mechanics.
+ Import of previous 'veteran' characters.. Practically no level limit..
+ Lots of skills.

Cons:

- The dialogue choices doesn't quite reflect what's being said. Quite often far from it. It's a gamble. How's that RPG?
- Quite often different dialogue options leads to the same result or none at all. Just for show.
- Once you are overloaded you can't sort through your entire inventory to scrap the least useful ones in favor of the last additions, which often happens to be a lot better than anything else you've got.. (Bleh, Of course).
- No three-some!! Just like any other BioWare game it enforce ancient and unnatural monogamous relationships.

And when i couldnt save Wrex? i restarted from my last save so i could save him, geuss what? i had to start at the beginning of the level. Another problem i have with the game is The ♥♥♥♥ing Mako. It is single handedly the worse vehicle i have ever drove in a game. When i was on the second last level, it was bounceing off walls, Barely going in a straight line, it was so bad i couldnt even get to the conduit. GEUSS WHAT I HAD TO REDO THAT WHOLE SECTION (even though the mako controlled better, I was still extremely frusterated). In Noveria (peak 15) And the second last level, Geuss what? Shepard and his crew, and most of the enemys were all black textures This completely ruined the atmosphere for me. The negatives are very negative. But the postives are extremely postive. The story is great, Very morbid, And at times inspirational. I suggest you level up your Charm/Intimadation levels because they are very handy. And if you dont have them you have no choice but making regretable decisions.This game is epic, and the sequels are ten times better. The choice making is great, Interaction is great. Fighting is okay. A.i is okay (depends on what difficulty i would assume) Is it worth 20 dollars? Probably not. it hasnt aged that well, i would say pick it up if its on sale, thats what i did. I love this game even if it frusterated me at times. just beware this game isnt perfect.

In conclusion. eh

reviewText:
Mass Effect is a story-rich FPS where you play as Shepard, in a time where the universe is starting to realise the potential of the human species in taking up bigger responsibilities alongside others. Initially under Captain Anderson's command, you are tasked to investigate a distress signal on a planet and during which, you discover that a trusted ally is setting something shady into motion. Throughout the game. you hunt him down and discover the secrets that would have implications on everyone in the known universe.

The game focuses strongly on the story, during which you would have to make a number of decisions that although may not change the story itself, they translate to your character stats, and also the (remaining) crew that you fight with. (And also your sex life lmao.) The combat system is pretty good in that you fight in a section of 3, where your crew could provide interesting powers or just be meat shields as you recharge your own powerups. However, some hostiles such as snipers or rocket turrets could possibly one-shot Shepard and you would have to restart from where the game last saved. Hence, I do recommend that you consistently manual save or you might have to replay a large part of the mission.

I find the game very well-rounded and enjoyable, back by an interesting story. However, one major set back to the action for me would be the extremely long elevator rides. Seems silly but you would have to play it to understand the agony :)

9.5/10

reviewText: I just got this for a couple of bucks, and after not playing it for several years, I got to say that this game has aged quite well in my opinion. For today's standards (regarding graphics and whatnot), it still holds up, and has some pretty good visuals. They do look a bit dated, of course, but for a game originally released in 2007, it looks great. Several people have complained about the Mako (driving) sections, and while the controls are a bit wonky, it still is a good idea, and it's not as bad as most people make it sound. And now,  let's talk about the heart of this game, and what makes it so special; the expanding, interesting, epic and completely immersive story filled with fully fleshed characters that you care about, amazing plot-twists, and an open ended narrative. This is what makes the ME series so special, along with it's bigger-than life space opera setting. Finally, I have to say that this game is a bargain. It offers at least 30 hours of gameplay, and if you explore every little corner and do every single side quests, those 30 hours could easily stretch to 50. Get this thing ASAP.

reviewText:
One of the best games, if not the best, I've ever played in my entire life.
Get lost in the storyline as you journey your way through space on the hunt for an evil rouge Spector named Saren.
You'll meet many characters whom you will fall in love with.
In fact, the characters in the game are so well developed that if one of them dies, you'll feel emotionally saddened by their death.
And that is the sign of excellent character development.
The game plays with your emotions as you are forced to make tough descisions between right and wrong.
Now the storyline is the best part, and that is something I will not be spoiling for you.
But if you enjoy the futuristic space theme and enjoy high-action RPGs, then this is the game for you!

reviewText:
What can I say about this game that already hasn't been said?

I'll try and do this game justice with what I'm about to write.

The story is brilliant and sets up the rest of the following games very well. Your choices matter and will affect the end result further down the line.
Character development is strong. With Garrus being my favourite team member. Seriously, that Turian is awesome. Male Shepard and Garrus are the best bromance I've ever seen in a game.
The RPG elements are in depth and gives you the opportunity to mould your character in any way you want.
The combat is slightly lacklustre, but it can be forgiven and doesn't detract from the core game.

One main negative that a lot of people didn't like was the Mako. Sure it was ungainly and could almost climb near vertical cliffs. But I rather enjoyed the exploration it opened up for you.
You could travel to a planet, land on it and search locations noted on your map. Most of these locations didn't add anything to the main story line, but for me it brought me into the world more, it added lore and detail to the world.

Mass Effect is starting to look slightly outdated these days, though that is a given considering that it's over 8 years old from its first release date.

Buy this game, just for the fact that it'll suck you in and prepare you for the awesome ride that is Mass Effect 2 and most of 3. (I won't go into the details of 3 here, but I'm sure most people know of what I'm on about).

reviewText:
It did a great job of introducing me to a whole bunch of new philosophical questions at a very basic level when I was 15-16. A great alternative to pamphlets when you need to talk to your 15 year old kid about ending the life support of some crazy lady's husband.

One of the available side-quests (colonist background) was one of my favorite moments in any game I've ever played, and was more touching to me than even something like Undertale was.

This game played a small role in shaping the person I am, but it did so by presenting me with options and making me choose from them - not by forcing me to play the galaxy's hero or villain. Highly recommended, although parts of the game do show their age these days.

reviewText:
Wow. What a fantastic experience this game was.

I've heard so much about this game before actually getting myself to finally play it. Mainly because I'm not a fan of SCI-FI or shooter. Well I wasn't, before I started Mass Effect.

This game is incredible. It will drag you in with it's fantastic gameplay, brilliantly written story with massive lore, amazing character development, beautiful music, beautiful landscapes, unique atmosphere, masterfully done voice acting and some of what are probably one of the most memorable characters in the game history.

This is one of the rare games I actually finished. I have the tendency to play too many things at once to focus on a single game alone. This game, however, was an exception and getting it was probably one of the best decisions I've made in my life. I got it on sales for an € or so, but it is not only worth it's original price, but double that.

I recommend this game to everyone everywhere that cherishes brilliant dialogues, deep character development, huge lore behind the main story, for people that don't want to just walk straight forward and shoot stuff, but for people that enjoy exploring the world they are in, for people that enjoy making decisions and think logically.

Truly a masterpiece.

reviewText: Story driven third person shooter. Lets you decide what happens to the galaxy. Will you punch a reported and it will have after affects for 2 games. Or will you answer her questions. It is all up to you.\nI absolutely love this game, the mechanics and leveling system are great, the 2 follow up games not so much. This is the most expansive Mass Effect game to date. I recommend playing it with MEUITM (Mass Effect Upgraded/Improved Textures and Meshes) It's a mod which makes the game simply look more attractive.

reviewText:
I've finally got around to beginning the Mass Effect series, and numero uno was a blast. An incredibly immersive, well crafted and believable universe, I found myself happily getting lost in the cultural depth and history created here, of the Geth, Krogan, Turian, Rachni and more. Mass Effect features a wide range of well written, memorable characters (Liara, Wrex, Garrus, Saren, Anderson, Sovereign, could go on), some great clever dialogue and many funny moments, as well as more painful ones as the consequences of your actions play out through the story. One of the best aspects of the game as you progress is simply getting to know your crewmates that you're choosing to work with mission by mission. The music is fantastic, and acts beautifully to create atmosphere and in binding all the various parts of the game together (Vigil, Galaxy Map theme i'm looking at you). For a title released in 2007/2008 the graphics seem to have endured really well, and again fit perfectly with the overall feel of the game. While you're exploring planets be sure to stop and take a few seconds at the summit of a mountain and look out at the vista before you, it's pretty damn gorgeous.

Gameplay wise, combat is fun and pretty well balanced, if a little on the easy side. I found biotic abilities particularly enjoyable, there's also a lot of room to customise gear and weapons as you see fit, especially later in the game. Movement is kept varied in space or on land, between exploring new worlds/buildings on foot or by roaming and driving up sheer cliffs in the Mako, hopping around the interior of the Normandy and navigating the Galaxy Map, there is a real and epic sense of scale here (Moon landing included), and the freedom to seek it out.

The only slight cons I can think of are somewhat repetitive sidequests; with a bouncy tin tank that has some infamous clunky manoeuvring, and slowpoke elevators (which excellent dialogue and hilarious music almost make up for). The inventory can become a bit tricky to manage. Worlds explored outside of main quests could also be more detailed and fleshed out in terms of content beyond markers on the map.

Summary: A brilliant and deeply satisfying narrative experience overall, and I will be coming back for more playthroughs after visiting the next installments of Mass Effect.

Just play it.

reviewText:
You know it, you love it, it's Mass Effect!

Have you ever wanted to be immersed in a believable, complex, engrossing science fiction tale that brings humanity into a galactic forum of sentient species from across the galaxy as they attempt to tackle an unknown nefarious threat?

Well? Have you? Of course you have!  What are you waiting for!   This game is...less polished than it could've been.  But if you get past the somewhat...lackluster FPS aspects, and focus more on the RPG-like progression of powerful abilities and the story driven aspects...there's nothing not to love.

Also, Jennifer Hale's voice acting as Femme-Shep is exquisitely charged with passion and verve!  Strong female protagonist, if you choose for Shepherd to be female.   I, frankly, found the male voice actor to be neutral in his emotions too often.  I don't believe he threw himself into the role as much.

Jennifer Hale sounds like she's the hero who held off a Batarian raid of a human colony single-handedly and against all odds.

Anyway, I digress.  If you have the money to burn, and want a good story, this is one of the best in sci-fi. (Mass Effect 3's ending being the only highly-contested part of that statement.)

The Normandy isn't going to command itself...

reviewText:
I admit that, even though I had heard so many good things about the ME series, I didn't actually try out the game until now. And even though it's not exactly state of the art anymore... it still managed to get me hooked quickly.
Yes, it's a few years old, yes, the graphics won't do well if compared to more recent games. But OMG, talk about an immersive game.
There are quite a few similarities to KOTOR 1 and 2... its obvious it's the same developer. So if you enjoyed the incredible stories in the KOTOR-games, give this a try. KOTOR of course also was fun because it was set in the SW-universe, and in a very interesting era of that franchise, the old republic. Jedis, the Force, the Dark side etc.
So I wasn't sure I'd warm up to a very different universe and franchise. And even though I haven't progressed very far yet, I already do care a lot about the story and the characters. Amazing.
The story IS captivating, and so is the combat. It's not the turn-based lightsaber/force-combat of KOTOR, of course - instead, its a tactical shooter, not turn-based. And it's FUN even though I'm usually not at all into that genre at all.
I haven't even used my squad that much, still warming up to controlling and using my companions but even without that deeper element of the game, I enjoy the action-part of the game a lot. Taking cover, using tactics, choosing your wep, trying to find a good tactic or going for the dangerous method... FUN. And again, I usually am not a fan of shooters.

The story is totally captivating and interesting. I am not sure whether the balance will work for everyone (sometimes, there is a lot of running around, talking to people etc, before it goes back to action), but for me it works.
And the speech Capt. Anderson gives to his crew rather early on in the game actually gave me goosebumps, I admit it. Heroic moment ftw.
The writing rocks, and so do the characters.

Now, keep in mind this game is a bit older. Apart from the graphics which isn't state of the art, there are some issues with the combat. Sometimes, you might be taking cover but can't fire for some reason. You can see the enemy, have a clear line of sight, yet can't shoot until you move a bit more. There are some issues with the Mako too...driving it can be fun, but I had some situations where it bounced like a rubber ball and fell off a cliff. Targeting with it has some issues too...clear line of sight at a drone, shoot, not hitting at all (keep in mind that you have to keep some distance in between the vehicle and enemies when using the Mako)

The game, like KOTOR shows you a very clear path to your objectives. So you won't run around forever to find a special room... the path is dictated to you rather clearly. This might bother some, I was ok with it. The Citadel is a bit confusing sometimes, but that's ok.

I am amazed by how quickly the game captivated me, and I'm not even far into it yet! I can perfectly understand just why this game is so popular and revered. DOn't let the age scare you away (same with Kotor, and this game looks much better). Amazing.
Edit: about 10 hrs in... the story gets even more interesting, and the game really makes you think about dialogue choices and decisions you make. It's not always black and white for sure, and I am planning on using my save games to continue through ME2 and 3, so I hope the choices are ok. If not, I'll start over =)

EDIT: OK, finished it. I didn't do a lot of the side-quests, focussed mainly on the storyline. I am rather certain I will at some point go back, start over, try some different choices and do the side-quests too.
Biggest complaint? It's TOO SHORT!!! (15.7 hours is what the Steam-counter says) However, it's thoroughly enjoyable. The storyline is totally fascinating, and often reminded me of the old Babylon 5-show regarding scope, mystery and background. Great writing, some fascinating twists, several fistpump-moments for the player.
No wonder this game is so popular and beloved. On to ME2 now!!

reviewText: The beginning of an epic saga! If you're not a fan already, then prepare to become one. In this well balanced RPG game, you call the shots as you lead a crack team of warriors on a mission to save the galaxy. The story is both engaging and intense, keeping you on the edge of your seat the whole way. Think carefully before making any decisions, as they can and will come back to haunt you in ME2 and 3. And prepare to get attached to your companions, as you may well lose them if you don't take care! While the gameplay itself can be buggy at times, it is incredibly intuitive given it was made in '07, though nowhere near as smooth as Crysis. For $20 you are getting something worth far more! So go ahead and download it! Yes I mean you, go ahead and click the download button! I can guarantee you won't regret it! And while you're at it, you might as well get Mass Effect 2, cuz you WILL be buying it after you get hooked on ME1. So save yourself the trouble and do it now. xD

reviewText:
Mass Effect is an incredible game, and the beginning to one of my favorite games of all time. This game has some of the most interesting characters in any game, and even after playing all three games in the series I still feel a connection to my squadmates. The replay value of this game is incredible as well, as you find yourself wanting to make different choices to see the effect on the outcome.

That being said, there are issues with the game. Specifically, the combat in the first Mass Effect is less than stellar. It isnt terrible, but the second and third games improve on it so heavily that it is hard to come back and play the first. Plus, the RPG elements of the game can get overwhelming (picking up hundreds of different types of armor, a lot of which you cant use) and managing your inventory can be a chore. The other big issue I have with this game (specifically for the Steam version) is the lack of controller support. This game originally came out on Xbox 360, yet the Steam version only allows keyboard and mouse. There are mods you can do to hack in support for controllers, but they are buggy and not even close to the polish of the Xbox 360 version. The Mouse+Keyboard controls are fine, but it bothers me that I can't use my input form of choice.

Overall though, this game is amazing. Highly recommend.

reviewText:
As someone who's more of a FPS player, I occasionaly like playing RPG's because of the immersive experience they deliver. I only played Fallout 3 and New Vegas aside from Mass Effect so I don't have much experience in these type of games but here goes.

The number one reason I kept playing through Mass Effect was the story. The game really let's you control how the story develops while being very interesting at the same time. It was very hard to get in to (haha..) and can be overwhelming for someone who has never played an RPG before, but when you get the hang of the skills, guns and inventory it will be pretty fun.

Although I have to say I don't like the combat apart from the usable skills. Yes, you have a plethora of options for your guns, but the guns themselves stay the same through out the game: pistol, shottie, rifle and sniper + grenades. Maybe because I liked the skills more I didn't like the gunplay that much. If you like modding your gun (attachments+ammo type) you probably would like this game but I liked the Fallout 3 weapon system more. The story blows you away and that's what counted the most for me. I liked doing side missions a lot more than combat, but that's me.

TL;DR: Want a great story + ♥♥♥♥ ton of upgrade options + items (although they're pretty much the same items with better stats)? Buy this game.

reviewText:
So I hadn't ever finished Mass Effect until just a few days ago but in those few hours that it took me to play the game through I thoroughly enjoyed it. The combat is fun, the story engaging, the graphics were fine and, overall, it felt like I WAS Shepard. The biggest compliment I can give this game is the story. It draws you in and absorbs you as you talk to all of these strange and fascinating characters and learn more about them and the worlds around them.

I do have some problems with it though. One of those problems stemming from the fact that, when I first started playing this game, I had no idea where I was supposed to go. The game doesn't always present a clear direction and, while I do appreciate the fact that the map lets you set your own waypoints, it just doesn't direct you the way you would like.

My biggest gripe with this game however comes in the form of combat. I do enjoy the combat of Mass Effect and it does keep you engaged but the controls are just not quite up to par. Mashing your face into the wall to take cover is not a good way of getting into cover. The later games in the series do this in a better way by mapping it to a button but here I often found myself just running against the nearest rock to get to cover and if that didn't work I would just run to the next one and so on and so forth.

That being said this game is still excellent. The story is intriguing and the characters just enhance that. I recommend playing this if just for the story and nothing else. In fact, this game is worth a playthrough just for Garrus Vakarian alone. He is the man.

reviewText:
This game made me abandon my love for Star Wars. I no longer enjoy Star Wars even though my friend is keen to remind me this is made by the same people that made KOTOR and that they only made this after they lost the license.

Regardless, this game is fantastic. I don't really think you need another positve review why this game is good but there you go.

Well balanced RPG skills and levelling. Along with action, combat. Dialogue.
Honestly this game is near perfect.

The only real issues are that the side missions are terrible, they all take place in the same warehouse.
There are a fair few bugs that seem to have you randomnly float and get stuck in things.
Graphical glitches as well. It's not all that polished but if you can get past that, then it's an experience you need to have.

An Open Letter to Toolbear:

Dear toolbear,

It has come to my attention that after all this time, since you first made fun of me for being dead on the internet, you have not said you're sorry. You should understand that this lets me, a dead guy on the internet, understand a lot about the person that you are (notice how I said person, not bear, you are not a bear you are a person on the internet and you need to come to terms with reality). From your actions I can tell that your average day consists of two things: 1) Wake up and jack off to furry bear porn and 2) Go to your computer and make fun of openly dead people on the internet. Now, keeping that in mind, lets see what I do with my day. The format will be the action followed by an explanation. Here is my day: 1) Wake up (yes dead people need sleep too if you didn't think that you're racist and should see a psychiatrist and shut yourself off from society) 2) Shower (see item 1 explanation) 3) Solve cold fusion (Ever since I died I have put 100% of my ghostly being into helping society, the fact that you are mean to me on the internet shows that you are worthless as a person (again I said person)) 4) Give the solution to everyone for free (see item 3 explanation) 5) Cure AIDS (You of all people should be interested in this item) 6) Give the cure to everyone for free (notice how you have not gotten the cure to AIDS, this is because you are no longer a person, you are less that dirt) 7) Bring about world piece (notice, again, that you have not seen this piece. This is because you do not deserve to see it, you are less than dirt) 8) Solve all the world's remaining problems (This is because I am a good creature, I am actually worth something, unlike you). I would hope that this list of my every day actions would change your mind when it comes to respecting dead people on the internet (like me), but I would not expect you to, because you are of absolutely no use to anything in this universe whatsoever. Unlike this game. Mass Effect has brought me some solace from your relentless attacks on my being. If it were not for this video game, I would have probably given up on helping this universe. Look around you (if you are not toolbear) and see all the good that this game has done to this world. I would highly recommend buying this game if you like RPGs and science fiction. 9/10

-[M8B] Jamestown (A dead guy on the internet)

reviewText:
What if I told you there was a science-fiction roleplaying game where you lead a vastly diverse crew to stop the Council's golden agent after he goes rogue?

Now, what if I told you that in said game, you make choices that can drastically effect multiple boss fights and just how diverse your crew is?

Now stay with me, what if I told you in said game, your dialogue tree has VOICED dialogue provided by Mark Meer (if you are playing male) or the lovely Jennifer Hale (if you are playing female, obviously.)

Okay, okay, sound interesting? Now how about this... What if I told you that this is Part 1 to a fully thought out and innovative trilogy where you can import not only your saves, but your very character (from your choices to your appearance) from the first game?

What if I told you this game also has low enough specs to be played on most laptops? Seriously, if you're a RPG fan and you haven't played this yet because the controversy of the third game's ending has discouraged you: play this trilogy anyways. This is a lore-filled game with a fully narrated codex. A fully narrated codex!!! You can spend hours just listening to the codex alone!

Seriously, the entire trilogy will provide you hundreds of hours of immersion in a well crafted universe.

Just buy this if you like roleplaying games of any sort.

reviewText:
Outstanding Western Rpg from Bioware, Mass Effect has it all, a compelling story, great gameplay and likeable characters that grow on you more and more. Story wise, Mass Effect isn't the best from the Bioware catalogue as I would consider Knights of the Old Republic to be the King there, however that doesn't undermine the fact that Bioware has crafted an original plot without straying too close to Star Wars.

I preferred the gameplay in Mass Effect over KOTOR as the blend of the third person shooter mixed with the rpg elements was a nice touch and I feel Mass Effect is more replayable as a result. There are many ways to build a character in Mass Effect and this felt streamlined and it felt like a nod to classic Rpg's with the typical classes you would find but adding a modern, science fiction twist.

I would thoroughly reccomend Mass Effect to any rpg fan and it proves that Western Rpgs can be just as good if not better than the Japanese counterparts and Bioware truly leads in example of how to create a  masterpiece Rpg with a Western touch.

reviewText: Well the big-♥♥♥ Space Opera RPG is pretty decent. It has got downsides, like having unremarkable gameplay resemblance to past Bioware games (most notably KotOR 1+2), elevator sim mini-games, half of the weapon and armor upgrades being completely useless, level scaling (why.jpg), copy-paste dungeon layouts (dungeon meaning the exact same buildings on every side-quest planet), and character building + skill trees that are so easy and limiting that it makes character/party builds in Final Fantasy VII look complex (which is not so surprising seeing the dichotomy between the KotOR games and their earlier games, Baldur's Gate for example). Also semi spoiler warning, the background lore and characters are very reminiscent of KotOR games. It is not direct copypaste but it is noticeable, but the quests and characters have their own unique flavors to them.\n\nBut what's great about it? The story, music, characters, and the element of choice in the game. I clocked 62 hours into the game because the characters in my party entertained me (mostly Wrex) and the feeling of traveling to distant galaxies to explore them (and there are MANY of them, you'll be playing for hours) as a captain of my own ship and alien crew was too much fun. I would recommend a playthrough.
