reviewText:
A long long time ago in a galaxy far away...


It was 2007, and Bioware launched their flagship title to the franchise we now know as Mass Effect.

Was it worthy of praise and sequels? Does it hold up today?

Yes, and yes.

First of all, the universe is immense, with detailed lore written and performed via audio journals.
(The games also spawned novelizations, merchandise, and a script for a movie has been in development since 2010)
The game was among the first exploring morality, choice, and consequences can lead you down different paths.

Aaaand here's where I lose some of you because of my opinion:

I like the Mass Effect universe more than Star Wars universe, in fact, I am not much of a fan at all of Star Wars, not even the original trilogy. There, I said it.

Did Star Wars inspire Mass Effect?

Duh.

I also like Doctor Who, Farscape, and other sci-fi worlds, and just take into consideration that a review is just an opinion.

Ok anyone still with me?

Why is Ashley Williams armor pink and white? It makes not one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ bit of sense. She's a marine, not a sex robot. Sure, you can buy Ashley some upgraded armor and retire the pink-and-white whywouldanyonewearthisinabattlefieldwhiteisimpossibletokeepcleannottomentionitsjustplainsexistatthispoint"
peice of armor to rest....

BUT WHY??!?!?!

So apart from a few minor gripes
date:
the game still crafts its story well and creates interesting choices for Shepard to face (even though "Renegade" Shepard is kind of a psychotic ♥♥♥♥ for no reason)

Final Verdict:

7.5/10 - Definitely worth putting in your collection
recommended: with ME2. Pity we'll never get ME3
hoursPlayed: but just go watch it on Youtube because ♥♥♥♥ EA.\n\nAnd if any of you make a sci-fi space epic

reviewText:
Mass Effect makes my heart flutter everytime I put it on.  It has such a vibrant galaxy to explore, great story and beautifully fleshed out characters. The choices you make have minor to major consequences throughout the game world and subsequently affect the 2 following games. 1 playthrough is close to 40hrs if you spend a lot of time exploring, though in a mass effect game 10 hrs of gameplay has more content than most games clocking over 100hrs, they have a real feeling of forward momentum and the pacing between quests or side quests never come across as feeling obtuse.

I did my first playthrough on the 360 as a  infiltrator class paragon and my 2nd on p.c as an adept paragon,  even though I was a paragon both times the game was different  on my 2nd playthrough due to different choices made. I plan on doing even another playthrough  as a renegade, which I'm very excited about because I don't have any idea how it's going to play out due to major choices that can be made. I recommend on either platform but the p.c version does have slightly better graphical quality and they really tightened up the controls with the keyboard and mouse.

This game feels like a lot of love, care and pride went into it and it shows, this game deserves to played.

reviewText:
I will give this game 7/10. The gameplay is quite decent, the difficulty seems fair MOST of the time.
The things that holds me from giving it a higher score is very anoying bugs.
1. You can get stuck in the elevator forcing you to reload the last save points.
2. There is a part where if you are hit you get stuck and you are forced to reload a check point.
3. The textures are extremly low quality and to get good quality you are forced to change the game files manualy.
The auto saves are also horrible, they have made me waste probably 40 min of my life since i was forced
to go back a long time after dying.

The port to Steam is so freaking bad, the DLC is forced to be manualy downloaded from EA's site and i can't even find the second DLC. The fact that Bioware just let bugs like these still be there is mind blowing, they just don't care about their game anymore and won't fix gamebreaking bugs. The fact that Steam didn't make the DLC available to the Steam client itself is also confusing.

But other than that the game is fun to play, im looking forward to play the rest of the Mass Effect series.

reviewText:
Got the Mass Effect pack for $10, including the original and ME2. I don't feel too bad I missed playing this back in 2008; overall, I'd give it 8/10.

The game's already been praised by plenty of people, so the bad:
Controls are not optimized as well as they could be; navigating dialogue options and the hacking minigames are very annoying with the mouse.

The game is short. When some of the characters in your party start referring to a bond being created, and I'm only 6 hours into the game, the story feels a little rushed.

Overall, this was $5 very well spent, but there's no way this game was worth full price.

reviewText:
Originally posted on June 28, 2010

Mass Effect is essentially the cross-breed result of mating Bioware's RPG formula with Gears of War's combat system.
The game is a console title first and foremost, which makes many of its flaws all the more apparent on the PC, however the art design, and story telling are top notch, and the roleplaying elements (through not as deep as the game would like you to think) are interesting enough

Graphics- The game features dated graphics technically speaking, even for the original release date. Incredibly low poly models, low res textures, and mediocre effect (particles) make this game less than awe inspiring visually. However the art design and character models are generally pretty good, especially when in comes to aliens, geth, and other creatures. The animations look quite good, and generally the art design is very creative. Cutscenes look quite good, generally speaking, although the overuse of bloom sometimes is annoying.

Yet the game is clearly custom tailored for the 5-year-old hardware of consoles, with irritatingly frequent load screens, jarringly low res skyboxes and other textures, and annoying amounts of loading zones masquerading as elevators.

Sound- Generally speaking, the music is superb, with a electronica soundtrack that harkens back to deus ex. The voice acting is also generally good, although there are a few rough spots, and the characters are generally memorable as a result. The sounds for weapons and other effects are also quite nice, providing a space age feel to the combat

Gameplay- My biggest problem with this game by far is the gameplay, as Bioware seems to have taken their typical RPG formula (which I have mixed feelings about) and mated it with Gears of War's cover and combat systems ( which I hate). Bioware's formula allows for alot of choices in the story, randomized loot drops, and other RPG staples. It is also notorious for lazy level design. absolute cookie cutter carbon copies of levels litter this game, quickly draining what little flavor the side quests hold for you from the game, as there is one generic mine level, two generic settlement levels, and one generic spaceship/station level that the player encounters AGAIN AND AGAIN throughout the game. At least Bethesda knows their level design, give them credit for that. Bioware's level design flat out sucks.

It doesn't end with cookie cutter levels however, for the driving sequences are equally frustrating. Exploring strange new worlds in a rover and finding hidden collectibles (tedious, but an RPG staple) along with side quests sounds fun in theory, but the Mako handles like a physics nightmare. In addition, some of the terrain is modeled with so few polygons and so extremely steeply that it is almost impossible to simply cruise around the planets. Instead the mako climbs impossible angles, flips and does barrel rolls (without taking damage of course) and gets caught on terrain. In addition, the turret has almost no traverse, and you only get half xp from kills in the mako, making the armaments almost useless. Driving quickly became on absolute nightmare for me, and I was using a mouse and keyboard. I can only imagine how those poor saps with controllers felt.

Third, the cover system is awful and unnecessary. I hate gears of war, or any third person cover shooter for that matter, on principle. So seeing this system in a game made by people who used to develop RPG's for the PC first is awful. It locks you into objects unnecessarily, makes it difficult to get out, and frequently got me killed, frustrating me to no end. It also leaves levels littered with absurd amounts of cover for you and your enemies to use. Not that this unrealistic feature mattered, as the favorite maneuver of most of the AI in the game is to charge straight at your guns.

Other features such as the leveling, perks and squad management worked better, but even those got clunky. For example there is no way to examine your crew member's stats while on the Normandy, so equipping them via the weapons lockers can be very confusing. Inventory management in general is clunky, and needs a menu that is actually designed for the PC. Finally, I found the fact that every member of your squad had one of each weapon, even if they weren't trained in its use, to be very odd, and the fact that armor and weapon stats were not tied to the model or skin of the item gets very confusing. The loot often felt... generic at best.


Ultimately, this game has a story that will draw you in and it can be a lot of fun to play, but it is full of irritating gameplay, so much so that I would almost recommend skipping all but a select few of the side missions. It has a large amount of replay value, with many classes available to play as and many ways to resolve a situation, (although not as many as you think, 2 dialog choices often result in Shepard saying the same exact thing, a false representation of a choice), and it will keep you playing for many hours. Just take it for what it is: Consolized.

reviewText:
The gameplay is sloppy for a cover based shooter and there are a bunch of bugs in the cover and camera mechanics. There are rediculously bad vehicle sections that don't fit with the rest of the game, resource gathering that feels like a chore, and the graphics were not very good when the game came out let alone now. Oh, and the inventory system is an afterthought forcing in some really crappy RPG mechics where they aren't needed. It's still well worth playing.

Why?

Because the story is incredible and you can load your choices into ME2 and later into ME3. Did I mention the story was incredible? Character based narrative is Mass Effect's bread and butter (that, and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ME3 ending that makes no sense). Seriously skilled story writing, voice acting, direction, pacing,

Also, a powergamer note, you really need to have a ME1 paragon save in order to get Jack and miranda to both stay loyal in ME2 (cause you need near 100% paragon to swing that trick). ME2 DLC removes this need tnough.

All that said, I might still recommend watching some ME1 youtube clips and skipping to chapter 2 which has almost no problems on a techincal side and an equally good story.

reviewText:
I've heard great things about the Mass Effect series, but never really took the chance to try it out. I was also somewhat discouraged to play this franchise because of all the criticism surrounding the ending to its story. However, thanks to the winter sale I was more willing to pick up and play this amazing franchise. I am glad I did.

Each of the games in the trilogy are great on their own, but together they help create an amazing story with a plethora of characters that adds a layer of depth and wonder to the game that completely immerses you into their world(s). Your adventures throughout the Mass Effect Universe will take you to numerous worlds and gripping action-packed battles. The phrase, it's the journey not the destination" has never held more true.

Some technical stuff (Mass Effect 1): the game is a 3rd person shooter with various different guns to choose from
date: your character also has special abilities to level up and learn
recommended: the graphics may be a little dated since we're in 2013
hoursPlayed: the actual game-play is easy to pick up but does feel awkward at times

Cons:

reviewText:
I've heard great things about the Mass Effect series, but never really took the chance to try it out. I was also somewhat discouraged to play this franchise because of all the criticism surrounding the ending to its story. However, thanks to the winter sale I was more willing to pick up and play this amazing franchise. I am glad I did.

Each of the games in the trilogy are great on their own, but together they help create an amazing story with a plethora of characters that adds a layer of depth and wonder to the game that completely immerses you into their world(s). Your adventures throughout the Mass Effect Universe will take you to numerous worlds and gripping action-packed battles. The phrase, it's the journey not the destination" has never held more true.

Some technical stuff (Mass Effect 1): the game is a 3rd person shooter with various different guns to choose from

reviewText:
(Recommended for the epicness and Asari love)

Mass Effect would have to be one of most visionary and consistant RPG series made in recent years. Testament to the depth and intricacy of the game and its world, I have beaten this game and its sequels several times. Each time, I have made different choices and experienced different events and even different outcomes. With the benefit of hindsight, choices made in Mass Effect drive events found in its sequels.

If comparing this first game to the rest of the games, it is reasonable to say that it is clunkier for sure, and it isn't the best version of the game out there. But problems can be persevered with. TextMOD can fix the textures of a certain Turian character, at least; and an INI edit can do the rest, particularly enabling 5.1 sound. However, once this is done, Mass Effect is perhaps the most memorable of the series for the wonder it inspires as an introduction to this rich universe and inspiring characters.

Bear in mind, however, that if you wish to use a game-pad, you will require an external mapping program, and there are some irritating quirks with mapping mouse movements to the stick. In Xpadder, I had to add a middle mouse click to all directions. See my guide and downloadable profile. ;)

Mass Effect was a revelation when it came out, and even know, though so much of its gloss has faded, it is mostly due to the rest ofthe trilogy being so fantastic in comparison. This entry to the story is mesmerising in its depth and clarity of execution. There has never been a more complete science fiction world ever invented for a video game.

reviewText:
Got the Mass Effect pack for $10, including the original and ME2. I don't feel too bad I missed playing this back in 2008; overall, I'd give it 8/10.

The game's already been praised by plenty of people, so the bad:
Controls are not optimized as well as they could be; navigating dialogue options and the hacking minigames are very annoying with the mouse.

The game is short. When some of the characters in your party start referring to a bond being created, and I'm only 6 hours into the game, the story feels a little rushed.

Overall, this was $5 very well spent, but there's no way this game was worth full price.

reviewText:
Originally posted on June 28, 2010

Mass Effect is essentially the cross-breed result of mating Bioware's RPG formula with Gears of War's combat system.
The game is a console title first and foremost, which makes many of its flaws all the more apparent on the PC, however the art design, and story telling are top notch, and the roleplaying elements (through not as deep as the game would like you to think) are interesting enough

Graphics- The game features dated graphics technically speaking, even for the original release date. Incredibly low poly models, low res textures, and mediocre effect (particles) make this game less than awe inspiring visually. However the art design and character models are generally pretty good, especially when in comes to aliens, geth, and other creatures. The animations look quite good, and generally the art design is very creative. Cutscenes look quite good, generally speaking, although the overuse of bloom sometimes is annoying.

Yet the game is clearly custom tailored for the 5-year-old hardware of consoles, with irritatingly frequent load screens, jarringly low res skyboxes and other textures, and annoying amounts of loading zones masquerading as elevators.

Sound- Generally speaking, the music is superb, with a electronica soundtrack that harkens back to deus ex. The voice acting is also generally good, although there are a few rough spots, and the characters are generally memorable as a result. The sounds for weapons and other effects are also quite nice, providing a space age feel to the combat

Gameplay- My biggest problem with this game by far is the gameplay, as Bioware seems to have taken their typical RPG formula (which I have mixed feelings about) and mated it with Gears of War's cover and combat systems ( which I hate). Bioware's formula allows for alot of choices in the story, randomized loot drops, and other RPG staples. It is also notorious for lazy level design. absolute cookie cutter carbon copies of levels litter this game, quickly draining what little flavor the side quests hold for you from the game, as there is one generic mine level, two generic settlement levels, and one generic spaceship/station level that the player encounters AGAIN AND AGAIN throughout the game. At least Bethesda knows their level design, give them credit for that. Bioware's level design flat out sucks.

It doesn't end with cookie cutter levels however, for the driving sequences are equally frustrating. Exploring strange new worlds in a rover and finding hidden collectibles (tedious, but an RPG staple) along with side quests sounds fun in theory, but the Mako handles like a physics nightmare. In addition, some of the terrain is modeled with so few polygons and so extremely steeply that it is almost impossible to simply cruise around the planets. Instead the mako climbs impossible angles, flips and does barrel rolls (without taking damage of course) and gets caught on terrain. In addition, the turret has almost no traverse, and you only get half xp from kills in the mako, making the armaments almost useless. Driving quickly became on absolute nightmare for me, and I was using a mouse and keyboard. I can only imagine how those poor saps with controllers felt.

Third, the cover system is awful and unnecessary. I hate gears of war, or any third person cover shooter for that matter, on principle. So seeing this system in a game made by people who used to develop RPG's for the PC first is awful. It locks you into objects unnecessarily, makes it difficult to get out, and frequently got me killed, frustrating me to no end. It also leaves levels littered with absurd amounts of cover for you and your enemies to use. Not that this unrealistic feature mattered, as the favorite maneuver of most of the AI in the game is to charge straight at your guns.

Other features such as the leveling, perks and squad management worked better, but even those got clunky. For example there is no way to examine your crew member's stats while on the Normandy, so equipping them via the weapons lockers can be very confusing. Inventory management in general is clunky, and needs a menu that is actually designed for the PC. Finally, I found the fact that every member of your squad had one of each weapon, even if they weren't trained in its use, to be very odd, and the fact that armor and weapon stats were not tied to the model or skin of the item gets very confusing. The loot often felt... generic at best.


Ultimately, this game has a story that will draw you in and it can be a lot of fun to play, but it is full of irritating gameplay, so much so that I would almost recommend skipping all but a select few of the side missions. It has a large amount of replay value, with many classes available to play as and many ways to resolve a situation, (although not as many as you think, 2 dialog choices often result in Shepard saying the same exact thing, a false representation of a choice), and it will keep you playing for many hours. Just take it for what it is: Consolized.

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying that I'm not the kind of gamer that would normally enjoy a game like ME. Trust me, not by a long shot. And I really couldn't tell you or remember what it was that finally made me give it a try. But I did, and I'm glad. A few years after I've now purchased and thorougly enjoyed the whole trilogy on my console (yes, I know, ewww a console gamer). And it all started with this fortuitous purchase. So I've come back after all this time because this game deserves a good review. It's that kind of game.
ME is a well done game. It's as simple as that. The story. The characters. The world and its lore, the sounds and visuals, the atmosphere, the style of the game. And of course, the gameplay. Balanced, yet challenging. Simple and straightforward yet deep, full of possibilities.
To be fair, some aspects of the game should be have been more streamlined. For example the equipment system. Another one is the planet exploration. ME is like the coolest, most interesting city with the slowest, most boring elevators. Speaking of which...
But no, I digress. If you're that last gamer who still hasn't tried ME, then I'm here to tell you your future self has sent me back in time to tell you that I'LL BE BA-no wait, wrong program... to tell you to give this game its chance. Take it from me, I'm that guy, just like you, who was expecting another loathsome shooter, ready to spew my bitter reproach back at the universe, but in the end just couldn't resist the charm of the game. Mass Effect DESERVES your gaming. On its own merits.

reviewText:
Combat
I know this is the first one and they were getting some ground, but this is the weakest of the mass effect series.
The combat is quirky and annoying where if you get close to a  wall you automatically get suction cupped onto it, and you have to waddle your way out. It would have just been easier to have a cover button. Meanwhile shooting, it's okay but your kinda op even with the normal guns, heck you could speed run without leaving starting weapons/armor.
4/10

Dialogue/Characters
Now this is the main reason I was interested in the games. The dialogue is very interesting and the story is very cool (especially the last battle) and you will stay immersed the entire time, until combat. The characters you find are cool and you will actually get a connection, they put more time into dialogue and characters rather than combat and it payed off, there isn't very much fighting and more talking which is great. The decisions you make actually hurt you and when you  get one of them killed you will feel like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for leaving them to die .
9/10

Enviroments
They put a lot of detail into the landscape and it is nice, I am not fond of using the rover though it feels clunky. I don't have much to say for this one though.
7/10

Final Verdict
The game is alright and I can understand them not putting too much effort into it, they didn't know how good it would be. But the Dialogue is great and the story holds up. They did fix the Combat in Mass Effect 2 which is fantastic.
Mass Effect 1 = 7/10
Not great but need to play if you want to get settled into the universe.
Though one last comment for those who played Mass Effect 2/3 what the heck happened to Ashley? She get plastic surgery and a spray tan or something?

reviewText:
The first Mass Effect is the best from all three, but it doesn't mean it's actually something to write home about. Well, at least to someone who read anything in his life beyond pornographic fan-fics and pretentious novels of 2000s. Unfortunately, the big chunk of post 2000 playerbase is made of the illitarate defined by the lowest possible denominator.

Mass Effect is a mediocre third person shooter with little character customization that offers 2 ways of playing the game. Shoot everything and shoot everything with space magic. Bare bones, if you add a typical HOT pop-a-mole combat philisophy implemented in this game, that doesn't even tries to cover (pathetic pun intended) itself.

One thing bugs me after my second playthrough. This game looks half-baked, or aborted in an early production phaze. There are parts of the game, where it seems that there was a creative spark somewhere, someone had a vision of a great s-f/space opera game, that wouldn't just make money, but will offer all s-f tropes and classics from all over in one place for everyone to enjoy. Then the writing started, art-direction department attempted to do something with style, aaaand... few weeks later they had to say eh - ♥♥♥♥ it". And left the game with few interesting places to visit
date: few Codex (in-game lore encyclopedia) entries and a whole lot of filler content probably made by unexperienced interns. I do believe that most of the content in the game is a work of unexperienced hacks
recommended: just look at the Mako part of the game. I don't believe it would be passable even for a student. It boils down to disattachment between the lore part of the game
hoursPlayed: and the actual gameplay. The lore
voteText: places and characters are giving you a premise of varied experiences
helpfulPercent: but at the end of the game it all boils down to TPS action in a terribly designed locations. C&C boil down to occasional speech check (and since no one will play without these skills maxed out
votesHelpful: everyone will get that option) that will end all filler quests non-violently with absolutely cringe-worthy dialogue lines. Just listen to the final dialogue with Saren. I couldn't help myself but laugh while listening to it. It's like taken straight from a terrible 10 years old s-f writer on the Internet. Just terrible.\n\nFor a buck it's worth checking out. Just prepare for some cringe-fest and a lot of autism-inducing activities."

reviewText:
Best ♥♥♥♥-in sci-fi game ever, Best Mass Effect game. Unlike the other two games it actually felt like a sci-fi rather than a coated James Bond movie. Shame that Bioware ended up in EA's bed, because what could have followed this game could have been 10x better than what got produced.

If you're wondering why this game is better? Play it. I'll give you some hints

1. It's actually an RPG - Something Bioware forgot in its sequels is giving the player choices that actually matter, in this you can truly feel like you're choosing your own path rather than having it forced on you

2. The Reapers - At this point, we didn't know much about the reapers, but that's why they were such a great plot point: because they were mysterious. Perhaps it would have been better that way, keeping the player in the dark about them while fighting them. Mass Effect 2 kind of lost the feeling that the Reapers generated and by Mass Effect 3 they pretty much took a back seat the ♥♥♥♥ing Cerberus

3. It gives you a villain to rally around - We all hated Saren, not because he was a bad character but because he was a bad guy, and he did that so well. Harbinger just assumed control of people, we had very little interaction with him.

4. Feels like an actual epic sci fi - What the sequels tried to do and failed is to keep the story epic while making it also feel like a summer thriller... bad move. Mass Effect throws environments at you that are really alien, combined with its freaky techno music that haunts you to the core. Sure, you often get the generic mountain planets, but I think they managed to make it work somewhat, and on that note

5. Exploration - I get it, this isn't the U.S.S. Enterprise, you're hunting a criminal, but that doesn't mean you can't have a look around while you're out and about. You get to read up on strange planets, (the galaxy map usage in this is better too), explore them in a hilariously buggy tank, and do whatever you want. They are empty, for the most part, but it still feels fun. ME2 kind of continued it, but the lack of vehicular exploratation (sans the hammer) really didn't give the same vibe. Don't get me started on resource hunting in ME3

There's a bunch of other stuff I didn't touch on. Is it perfect? Hell no, it definitely has flaws, but I rather would have seen them get fixed instead of axed in the second game. It's really quite sad.

♥♥♥♥ you EA

reviewText: This is amazing! It could have been a movie because the story is awesome! Even if you don't play games you can play this one on the easiest difficulty just for it's story-- well, if you like science fiction, that is... It's very addictive. It makes you want to see what's next. There is even a ton of information that you can learn about the game's  fantastic world. Lots of new technologies and species and stuff like that. There are three main combat styles that you can use-- weapons, tech" abilities and "biotic" abilities
date: which are new ways to manipulate the matter and the energy
recommended: kind of like the Force in Star Wars. There are six classes that you can play and each one has its strengths
hoursPlayed: weaknesses and unique set of skills and you have to work together with your followers to beat every kind of enemy. Each one of your followers has their own personality and story and some of them even give you a small quest to play. Many times you will be given the chance to make a choice between two or more decisions to take
voteText: usually a "good" one and a "bad" one. You can be a "good guy" or a "bad guy". Well
helpfulPercent: not really a *bad* guy... You save the galaxy either way
votesHelpful: you can just choose to do it the right way
votesTotal: or any way you like. Even when talking to a character you can choose a "good" polite response or a "bad" rude one. What i didn't like is that all the weapons and any kind of equipment look and function alike. Even their names are boring (for example Lancer III
votesFunny: Lancer IV
commentsCount: Avenger VIII
column17: etc...) It would have been a lot better if there were unique items with a unique way to function and even special abilities
column18: like for example a "Prototype Alpha Bio-Blaster". Also the planets you can explore get a little boring after a while. Another thing i didn't like is that there is no stealth
column19: so you always have to fight your enemies. Except of course if you talk them out of it-- there is a way to persuade other characters using "charm" or "intimidation". You could also find it a bit annoying that your enemies always repeat the same thing during a battle ("Enemy is everywhere!") and there are some technical problems too
column20: but if you can overlook that
column21: you have a damn good game with an excellent story that will bring you many hours of fun."

reviewText:
I love this game... so great ! Awesome graphics, fun gameplay. It's pretty much an RPG with shooter elements. Took me about 40 hours to finish completely back then, so it's really worth the money. Anyhow, along the way you do quests for people and find (upgradeable) loot, and shoot a whole lot of aliens. Hated the elevator scenes; they took really long, so I was glad they got rid of it in Mass Effect 2. The story ? Superb, with lots of choices.
Don't miss out on one of the greatest games ever.

[Rating: 95/100]

reviewText: Mass Effect is both complex and amazing. Through your first time playing the game, you might not full understand everything and will most likely end up playing it again to understand everything more clearly. Very fun game to play indeed, challenging, stable  and exciting storyline, and so damn fun. Everything you do in the game will both affect the game later on, as well as the 2 sequels. After you finish each game, you can import your character saves from the prequel and continue on. You have to remember, this is also an adventure game. You need to to explore and find things out yourself and not just depend so much on the game to do it for you. I just love this game, I hope they put Mass Effect 3 on steam soon.

reviewText:
Mass Effect:

Positives:

+ A very narrative centered game filled with decisions which impact the way your character is perceived and how the world develops around you.
+ Lots of dialogue explaining the background and plot of the title, so you become immersed in the story.
+ Interesting array of weapons, with modifications which can increase weapon stability, damage, heat absorption and more.
+ Mass Effect combines RPG and shooter elements to make an interesting action packed game. Level up your party by gaining experience from quests, killing enemies or decrypting locked cases. You can spend talent points to upgrade your skills in firearms, combat armour, health, electronics and more.

Negatives:

- For an RPG it isn't the longest game, taking around 45-60 hours to finish. I explored a lot of the galaxies and the main questline is sort of short. I didn't see everything the game had to offer but for the most part I did.
- Graphics are really dated for a game released in 2008. In comparison, the Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion which hit the market in 2006, looks far superior. Nevertheless, you'll get used to it the more you play.
- Inventory system isn't streamlined and a bit clunky, room for improvement here.

Overall Score: 8/10

There's something about Mass Effect that makes it a really intriguing RPG. It's approach is fresh, it stands out from the standard medieval style RPG's due to its futurisitc sci-fi outlook. Well worth picking this one up on sale.
